Colors>Day 4 and onwards>After 2nd Midday>Automatic scene: 19>Choice: Triangle|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} If the player choose to confirm the student council's word, Kallen becomes shocked and embarrassed and the student council members becomes surprised and cheerful.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%203)%20Number-19%20(ScAutomatic-19),%20X.doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 4 and onwards>After 2nd Midday>Automatic scene: 19>Choice: X|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} After the two left, they decided to go to Shinjuku Ghetto, to search for a clue on Rai's identity. While searching through the ghetto, Kallen notice Rai recognizing a building and suspect Rai was Japanese, then notice Kallen's face brightened up.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors,%20(Automatic)%20(After%20Auto-19,%201%20to%203)%20Number-20%20(ScAutomatic-20)%20(2%20Choices)%20(Knightmare%20Battle).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 5 and onwards>Morning after Auto-19>Automatic scene: 20|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} If the player chooses to say if she laughed at him, Kallen denies it and decides to look around more.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%20Auto-19,%201%20to%203)%20Number-20%20(ScAutomatic-20),%201st%20Choice,%20Triangle%20(Knightmare%20Battle).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 5 and onwards>Morning after Auto-19>Automatic scene: 20>Choice 1: Triangle|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} If the player choose to say if she's happy, Kallen replied that he had remembered something since she's been keeping him company, which Rai thanked her.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%20Auto-19,%201%20to%203)%20Number-20%20(ScAutomatic-20),%201st%20Choice,%20X%20(Knightmare%20Battle).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 5 and onwards>Morning after Auto-19>Automatic scene: 20>Choice 1: X|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} Later, the two are caught in a battle by a group of Anti-Britannian terrorists with ''Burai'' Kightmare Frames pretending to be the Black Knights and a group of Britannian ''Sutherlands'' and Knight Police Frames. As they try to escape, they see a ''Burai'' falling onto them. If the player chooses to Protect Kallen, Rai immediately grabs Kallen in between his arms and turned his back towards the ''Burai''.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%20Auto-19,%201%20to%203)%20Number-20%20(ScAutomatic-20),%202nd%20Choice,%20Triangle%20(Knightmare%20Battle).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 5 and onwards>Morning after Auto-19>Automatic scene: 20>Choice 2: Triangle|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} If the player chooses to thrust Kallen away, Rai lied face down on the ground, knocking Kallen to the ground as well.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%20Auto-19,%201%20to%203)%20Number-20%20(ScAutomatic-20),%202nd%20Choice,%20X%20(Knightmare%20Battle).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 5 and onwards>Morning after Auto-19>Automatic scene: 20>Choice 2: X|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} The two later went in the damaged ''Burai'', with Rai piloting it visually as the hatch can’t close while Kallen wrapped around his body and tried to escape, but later encountered a Sutherland who was targeting the ''Burai'' and started to attack. However Rai managed to defeat him easily, which led Kallen to become surprised and impressed. They later encountered the real Black Knights defeating both the terrorists and the Britannian army while they were helping the civilians escape, leading Kallen to have them recognize her and let them leave.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Automatic),%20(Knightmare%20Battle)%20During%20Scene-20.doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 5 and onwards>Morning after Auto-19>Automatic scene: 20>Knightmare Battle Scene|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} The next day in Ashford Academy, Kallen meets Rai in the courtyard and request she would talk to him in the rooftops involving the battle at Shinjuku. Kallen then asked Rai how he knew to easily pilot a Knightmare, which he replied that he just knew.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors,%20(Automatic)%20(Day%20after%20Auto-20,%201)%20Number-21%20(ScAutomatic-21)%20(Choice).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 6 and onwards>Day after Auto-20>Automatic scene: 21|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} If the player choose to say if he was a Britannian who was in the army before, Kallen thinks of it as a possibility.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(Day%20after%20Auto-20,%201)%20Number-21%20(ScAutomatic-21),%20Triangle.doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 6 and onwards>Day after Auto-20>Automatic scene: 21> Choice: Triangle|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} If the player choose to say what Kallen thinks, she replied the possibility of Rai being a soldier of a Japanese resistance cell, which Rai thinks of himself as a dangerous person, but Kallen comments that he should be happy about the clues of his identity increased.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(Day%20after%20Auto-20,%201)%20Number-21%20(ScAutomatic-21),%20X.doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 6 and onwards>Day after Auto-20>Automatic scene: 21> Choice: X|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} During lunch break after their discussion, both Kallen and Rai went to the cafeteria together, which cause the attention to the other students there, which both don't know why. Later Rivalz appeared with Lelouch and has teased them for the two being a couple after a rumor mentioning her relationship with Rai went well and the incident involving the two in the Shinjuku ghetto, which includes Rai protecting Kallen. The rumor has shocked Kallen and Rai, with Lelouch thanked Rai for his deed and Rivalz curious to know what. Although Kallen had confirmed that Rai had saved her, she was annoyed by Rivalz's constant bickering, which led to Lelouch convincing him not to bother her more.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors,%20(Automatic)%20(After%20Auto-21,%202)%20Number-22%20(ScAutomatic-22).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 6 and onwards>After Auto-21, 1st Midday>Automatic scene: 22|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} Kallen later went to the Black Knight's hideout and meets with Zero to report about what happened in Shinjuku ghetto and revealed to him about Rai and his piloting skills. This report got Zero interested and was recommended by Kallen that he would join the Black Knights. {{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors,%20(Automatic)%20(After%203)%20Number-23%20(ScAutomatic-23).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 6 and onwards>After 2nd Midday>Automatic scene 23|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} The next day, Kallen waited for Rai from his chess match with Lelouch and sent him a signal to follow her,[http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors,%20(Ashford)%20Clubhouse,%20Student%20Council%20Room,%20(2,3)%20Lelouch,%20Kallen,%20Shirley,%20Rivalz,%20Nina%20(ScAsh-クラブハウス%20%7B生徒会室%7D-Le-Ka-Shi-Ri-Ni-01)%20(Choice).doc Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 10 and onwards>Either Midday>Ashford scene: Clubhouse>Student Council Room] which the player will choose to follow her right away,[http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Ashford)%20Clubhouse,%20Student%20Council%20Room,%20(2,3)%20Lelouch,%20Kallen,%20Shirley,%20Rivalz,%20Nina%20(ScAsh-クラブハウス%20%7B生徒会室%7D-Le-Ka-Shi-Ri-Ni-01),%20Triangle.doc Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 10 and onwards>Either Midday>Ashford scene: Clubhouse>Student Council Room>Choice: Triangle] or follow her after a little while,[http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Ashford)%20Clubhouse,%20Student%20Council%20Room,%20(2,3)%20Lelouch,%20Kallen,%20Shirley,%20Rivalz,%20Nina%20(ScAsh-クラブハウス%20%7B生徒会室%7D-Le-Ka-Shi-Ri-Ni-01),%20X.doc Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 10 and onwards>Either Midday>Ashford scene: Clubhouse>Student Council Room> Choice: X] and meet Kallen in the School garden, who then given him an invitation to meet her. The next day, Kallen waited for Rai at the Ghetto Ruins, witnessed his arrival and revealed her true self to him, which slightly surprised Rai. Kallen then led Rai to an Underground Tunnel and requested him to join her to fight against Britannia, believing him to be Japanese, which has confused Rai. The two arrived at an Abandoned Building and Kallen introduces him to Zero and revealed herself as Kallen Kouzuki, a member of the Black Knights. Kallen also requested Rai to join them, and requested to Zero for his admission, which Zero let Rai to decide, but noted they will take measures to protect their secret.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors,%20(Automatic)%20(After%203)%20Number-25%20(ScAutomatic-25)%20(Choice).doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 11 and onwards>After 2nd Midday >Automatic scene: 25|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} If the player chooses to have no choice{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%203)%20Number-25%20(ScAutomatic-25),%20Triangle.doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 11 and onwards>After 2nd Midday >Automatic scene: 25>Choice: Triangle|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} or accepts to join,{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%203)%20Number-25%20(ScAutomatic-25),%20Square.doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 11 and onwards>After 2nd Midday >Automatic scene: 25>Choice: Square|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} Kallen becomes pleased. However, if the player chooses that he is unsure, Kallen becomes shocked when Zero noted his silence mean he refused and prepares to open fire, but Kallen shielded Rai and begged him to join and revealed to him the Black Knights have an intelligence network to discover clues involving his past, leading Rai to have no choice but to join the Black Knights, but comments he will only trust Kallen.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors%20(Choices),%20(Automatic)%20(After%203)%20Number-25%20(ScAutomatic-25),%20O.doc|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 11 and onwards>After 2nd Midday >Automatic scene: 25>Choice: O|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2018}} In the ''Black Knights'' Route, Rai stops Princess Euphemia from following through with Lelouch's accidental Geass command (an alternate version to episode 22–23), which he was shot in the process. After Rai woke up and was healed, Kallen shows a great deal of gratitude toward Rai for saving the Japanese and shead in tears as Rai is alive and the two embrace each other as they kiss. Afterwards Rai and Kallen continue to be faithful members of the Black Knights. ====''Geass Route''==== In the ''Geass Route'' ending, Kallen was in the hangar tuning her ''Guren'' and was approached by Rai who wanted to talk to her. When Rai revealed that he's leaving the Black Knights, Kallen was shocked and demanded a reason from him. This led to Rai telling her that he has an illness and doesn't know how long he has left. After hearing this, Kallen ordered him to cure his illness and return. After Rai had left the hangar, Kallen turned to her ''Guren'' and slammed her fist in anger and sadness.{{cite web|url=http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/loc-hangar.php|title=Code Geass: Lost Colors Translation|author=|date=|website=code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com|accessdate=30 May 2018}}[http://code-geass-lost-colors-translation.yolasite.com/resources/Lost%20Colors,%20(Ashford)%20Black%20Knights%20Hideout,%20Hangar,%20(2,3)%20Kallen%20(ScTok-黒の騎士団アジト%20%7B格納庫%7D-Ka-01)%20(Geass%20Route%20End%20Scene).doc Code Geass: Lost Colors>Day 21 or 22>Times: Both Middays>Tokyo scene: Black Knights’ Hideout>Hangar>Characters: Kallen (Geass Route End Scene)] ===''Code Geass (manga)''=== The manga differs from the real series focusing on the Black Knights activities; in the manga Kallen is not present during C.C's appearance. Lelouch's first meeting with her is also different as she bumps into him at school. Kallen protests at the school rather than at the settlement. She is also apparently Zero's only soldier as only she helps him, such as when they rescue Suzaku. ===''Nightmare of Nunnally''=== In the manga spin-off series ''Nightmare of Nunnally'', Kallen and the other Resistance members took advantage of the arrival of Nunnally's ''Mark Nemo'' Knightmare Frame to make their escape from Britannian forces pursuing them. When Kallen escapes from the rooftops after she was taken hostage with the other student council members in a hotel at Lake Kawaguchi, she witnesses the arrival of the Mark Nemo. She later met up with Zero, who gave her a suitcase with the Black Knights uniform. In the battle against Cornelia's forces in the Saitama ghetto, she met up with the Mark Nemo again and witness it destroying all of the Britannian forces, and thought it was on their side, but disagrees and starts to attack Kallen and her group. She was surprised that it knew her moves before it happened and was defeated. ===''Suzaku of the Counterattack''=== In the manga spin-off ''Suzaku of the Counterattack'', Kallen becomes a member of the Black Knight after Zero forms the organization, but has doubts about his methods after a Black Knights faction had gone renegade and orchestrated an attack, taking the lives of nearby civilians, including Lenard Lubie. When Zero is planning to attack the Britannian Art Gallery with the goal of assassinating the Emperor who has arrived there, Kallen confronted him about whether it would be a trap and also commented that she would still follow him. Admiring her answer and loyalty, Lelouch placed a geass command on her that if anything would happen to him then she would lead the Black Knights. When the Black Knights took the Art Gallery hostage, she is confronted by Suzaku and was surprised that she's not only a member but a half Britannian-Japanese right after he left to stop Zero from killing the Emperor. After Lelouch was captured and accused for killing the Emperor, Kallen assume leadership of the Black Knights as the new Zero and later led the remaining Black Knight members to begin an assault on the Governor Building of Area 11, unaware that Lelouch is freed by Suzaku and are both planning to stop Schneizel. Five years later, a 22-year-old Kallen is seen walking on the street and still a member of the Black Knights and in contact, but while she was passing by, she suddenly saw someone who resembles a 17-year-old Suzaku, which she thinks she's imagine it. ===''Another Century's Episode: R''=== Kallen makes an appearance in the ''[[Another Century's Episode: R]]'' video game in her Knightmare Frame, the ''Guren'' Mk-II in an alternative event of R2. Kallen appeared in her world, in an alternative event of episode 6 of the second season, on a mission in her ''Guren Nishki'' to destroy a group of ''Caerleon'' battle ships until a group of ''Sutherland'' Knightmares appears. Kallen manages to defeat them all, but her ''Guren'''s radiation surge wave arm was badly damaged, but also fell when the ship began to shake, which led Rakshata to send her unit to transform her ''Guren Nishki'' to the ''Guren Kashōshiki''. She later proceeds to destroy the other ''Caerleon'' along with Todoh in his ''Zangetsu'' Knightmare and encountered Suzaku in his ''Lancelot'' along with Gino in his ''Tristan'' and Anya in her ''Mordred''. Kallen had fought the three and defeated them, causing Suzaku to order a retreat to the Chinese Federation.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xy2Xl9z9fGs Another Century's Episode R - Guren Kashōshiki Gameplay After Zero kidnaps Empress Tianzi, Kallen fought against Xingke in his Knightmare Frame, ''Shen Hu'', while defending the ''Ikaruga'' flagship from being attacked by a group of ''Gun Ru'''s. After the Enuches plans were exposed to the media, Kallen, along with Zero, C.C., and Xingke, have worked together and attack the Enuches land fortress, ''Leung Tan'', leading them to their deaths while the fortress explode. After being confronted by a fleet of Britannian Knightmares, including the four Rounds, the group encountered an unknown Black Hole and Kallen was sucked in along with Zero and C.C.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YFfGdaMyvWg|title=YouTube|author=|date=|website=www.youtube.com|accessdate=30 May 2018}} ===''Super Robot Wars Z 2 Hakai-Hen''=== Kallen and the rest of the Code Geass R1 cast will make their debut to the Super Robot Wars franchise in this game, using their R1 Knightmares. ===''Nunnally in Wonderland''=== In a special OVA parody episode, based on the ''[[Alice in Wonderland]]'' story, Kallen appears in the role as the March Hare.Code Geass: Nunnally in Wonderland ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Code Geass}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stadtfeld, Kallen}} [[Category:Code Geass characters]] [[Category:Fictional activists]] [[Category:Fictional aviators]] [[Category:Fictional bodyguards]] [[Category:Fictional military captains]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2006]] [[Category:Anime and manga martial artists]] [[Category:Fictional special forces personnel]] [[Category:Fictional women soldiers and warriors]] [[Category:Fictional child soldiers]] [[Category:Fictional revolutionaries]] [[Category:Female characters in anime and manga]] [[Category:Fictional Japanese people in anime and manga]] [[Category:Teenage characters in anime and manga]] [[Category:Teenage characters in television]]

{{Infobox person | name = Karin Magnussen | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1908|02|09}} | birth_place = [[Bremen]], [[German Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1997|02|19|1908|02|09|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Bremen]], [[Germany]] | years_active = | occupation = | spouse = | children = | birth_name = | parents = Walter Magnussen }} '''Karin Magnussen''' (9 February 1908 – 19 February 1997) was a German biologist, teacher and researcher at the [[Kaiser Wilhelm Institute of Anthropology, Human Heredity, and Eugenics]] during the [[Third Reich]]. She is known for her 1936 publication "Race and Population Policy Tools", and her studies of [[heterochromia iridis]] (different-colored eyes) using iris specimens, supplied by [[Josef Mengele]], from [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] victims. == Early life and education == Karin Magnussen, daughter of the landscape painter and ceramist Walter Magnussen, grew up with her sister in a middle-class home. She completed her schooling in Bremen, graduating with a degree. She then studied biology, geology, chemistry and physics at the University of Göttingen. Magnussen joined the [[National Socialist German Students' League]] (NSDStB) while she was still an undergraduate in college. By 1931, at the age of 23 years, she was a member of the [[Nazi Party|National Socialist German Workers Party]]. Later, she became a leader of the [[League of German Girls]] (Bund Deutscher Mädel, or BDM) and a member of the [[National Socialist Teachers League]]. As a BDM leader, she held lectures on the politics of race and population. She graduated in 1932 with an examination in the subjects of botany, zoology and geology. In July 1932, her thesis was accepted: ''Studies on the physiology of the butterfly wing''.{{cite web|url=http://www.estherlederberg.com/Eugenics%20%28CSHL_List%29/Karin%20Magnussen.html|title=Eugenics - Karin Magnussen|publisher=Esther M. Zimmer Lederberg Memorial Website }} After receiving her doctorate, she studied at the Zoological Institute of the University of Göttingen in Alfred Kühn. She placed first and later second on her state exam for a high school teaching position; ''inter alia'' in biology in 1936. In Hanover, Magnussen was employed as a teacher at a secondary school. Magnussen possibly modeled herself after "...the biologist Agnes Bluhm, who worked at the Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut fur Biologie and wrote "Die rassenhygienischen Aufgaben des weiblichen Arztes", Berlin, 1934, and who unhesitatingly supported Hitler's regime." In 1935, Magnussen went to work in the Nazi Racial Policy Office in the District of Hanover. A year later, she wrote ''Race and Population Policy Tools''. ==National Socialist views == Magnussen had already joined the National Socialist German Student League (NSDStB) during her studies. In 1931, she became a member of the NSDAP. Later, she became BDM leader and was a member of the National Socialist Teachers League (NSLB).Ernst Klee: ''Das Personenlexikon zum Dritten Reich'', Frankfurt am Main 2007, p. 387 In Bremen, she lectured on racism and demographics. Magnussen was BDM leader in the [[Gau (country subdivision)|Gau]]. In 1935, she was employed in the Gau Hannover in the Racial Politics Office.Sascha Hönighaus: ''Karin Magnussen'', Berlin 2007, p. 193f. Her publication of ''Race and Population Policy Tools'' appeared in 1936. In 1939, this work was published by Lehmann of Munich. After the end of the Second World War, in the Soviet zone of occupation, it appeared on the list of prohibited literature.Deutsche Verwaltung für Volksbildung in der sowjetischen Besatzungszone, ''Liste der auszusondernden Literatur'', Berlin: Zentralverlag, 1946 In the third published edition of 1943, Magnussen expressed the following:
"This war is not just about the preservation of the German people, but is about the question, which races and peoples should live in the future on European soil.... Basically England had no interest in the prosecution of this war, but it is a very different people, working parasitically behind the scenes and which is afraid to lose everything. In all of the enemy States, Judaism has significant influence. And just as Judaism had probably the clearest recognition that in the decisive struggle, the question of them was to be decided. The current war must therefore be also about the repression of the black danger in the West and the elimination of the Bolshevik threat in the East, which still resolves a racial problem in Europe, which all States are more or less interested in: the Jewish question. Also the Jew who enjoys life as a host in our country, is our enemy, even if he does not actively engage with weapons in this fight. …From the European point of view, the Jewish question is resolved in that the emigrant Jews do the thinking for the leaders in the other States. We have seen that these emigrants are only troublesome and set up the peoples against each other."From her book ''Rassen- und bevölkerungspolitisches Rüstzeug''. 3. Aufl. Lehmanns, München 1943, p. 201-203. ''Mit "Schwarze Gefahr" sind vermutlich Afrikaner gemeint, vgl. Rheinlandbastarde, ein beliebtes NS-Feindbild''
== Kaiser Wilhelm Institute == Due to receiving a scholarship, Magnussen was suspended in the fall of 1941 from her teaching profession and moved to the [[Kaiser Wilhelm Institute of Anthropology, Human Heredity, and Eugenics]] (KWI-A), in Berlin-Dahlem.Ernst Klee: ''Das Personenlexikon zum Dritten Reich'', Frankfurt am Main 2007, p. 387. From this time on, she worked in the Department of Experimental Pathology of Heritage under the Department head, Hans Nachtsheim. Her research focused on the inheritance of eye color in rabbits and humans.Wolfgang Schieder, Achim Trunk: ''Adolf Butenandt und die Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gesellschaft: Wissenschaft, Industrie und Politik im Dritten Reich'', Göttingen 2004, p. 297f. Her particular interest was the Heterochromic iris that she had examined since 1938. Magnussen used the scientific method to lead her to the conclusion that the eye is not only genetically, but also hormonally-determined. While there, she initially undertook studies on rabbit eyes.Sascha Hönighaus: ''Karin Magnussen'', Berlin 2007, p. 195 In July 1943, she was the research assistant of [[Otmar Freiherr von Verschuer]], at the KWI-A. At the KWI-A she also met Dr Mengele, who worked there temporarily. The Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) promoted her study to "explore the heritage conditionality for the development of eye color as a basis for racial and ethnicity studies" in 1943, in addition to eight other research projects at the KWI-A. This project was overseen and the publication edited by Magnussen.Hans Hesse: "Ich konnte nicht auf die Auswertung eines so wertvollen Materials verzichten - Augen aus Auschwitz: Das Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Anthropologie und der Fall Karin Magnussen", ''WeltOnline'', 31 August 2001Hans-Walter Schmuhl: ''Grenzüberschreitungen. Das Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Anthropologie, menschliche Erblehre und Eugenik 1927–1945. Geschichte der Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gesellschaft im Nationalsozialismus'', Vol. 9. Wallstein, Göttingen 2005, p. 370 == Auschwitz-Birkenau == From a colleague, she received the information that more twins and family members with Heterochromic irises would be found in the [[Sinti]] family in [[Mechau]] from northern Germany. Members of the family were taken in the spring of 1943 to the KWI-A, where they were photographed. In March 1943, the Sinti family in the [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] was deported, where Mengele had worked since late May 1943 as camp physician. This circumstance allowed Mengele to carry out the experiments (that Magnussen had done on rabbits) on the people. [[File:WP Josef Mengele 1956.jpg|240px|right|thumb|Josef Mengele in 1956. Photo taken by a police photographer in Buenos Aires for Mengele's Argentine identification document.]] According to a statement by Magnussen, Mengele dealt, among other things, with the eyes of these Sinti family using hormonal substances. Often, these painful interventions resulted in suppuration of the eyes and blindness of the victims. These experiments aimed at the investigation and eradication of the abnormality in people with Heterochromic Irises. In the event of death of the prisoners, Mengele pledged to Magnussen to give her the eyes of the victims for further research and evaluation.Rolf Winau: ''Medizinische Exeperimente in Konzentrationslagern'', Wolfgang Benz, Barbara Distel (Hrsg.): ''Der Ort des Terrors – Geschichte der nationalsozialistischen Konzentrationslager'', Vol. 1: Die Organisation des Terrors, C.H. Beck, München 2005, {{ISBN|3-406-52961-5}}, p. 174. In the second half of 1944, Magnussen received the eyes of the experiment victims from Auschwitz-Birkenau in several deliveries.Ilkka Remes: ''Das Erbe des Bösen'', p. 3 (pdf). No fewer than 40 pairs of eyes should have been received by Magnussen from Auschwitz-Birkenau.Sascha Hönighaus: ''Karin Magnussen'', Berlin 2007, p. 197 The Hungarian prisoner pathologist [[Miklós Nyiszli]] noted after the autopsy of Sinti twins that they had been killed, not due to illness, but because of a chloroform injection to the heart. Nyiszli had to prepare their eyes and send them to the KWI-A. == After the war == At least until the spring of 1945, Magnussen was working in Berlin.Ernst Klee: ''Auschwitz, die NS-Medizin und ihre Opfer'', Frankfurt am Main 1997, p. 486. After the end of the Second World War, Magnussen moved to Bremen again and continued her research. Her completed research was published in 1949, being entitled ''"On the relationship between histological distribution of pigment, Iris color and pigmentation of the eyeball of the human eye''."Hans-Walter Schmuhl: ''Grenzüberschreitungen. Das Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Anthropologie, menschliche Erblehre und Eugenik 1927–1945. Geschichte der Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gesellschaft im Nationalsozialismus'', Vol. 9 Wallstein, Göttingen 2005, p. 490 She was later denazified in Bremen. In 1950, Magnussen taught at a girls' high school in Bremen. She worked as study counselor and official, including the teaching of biology. She was considered a popular teacher who led an interesting biology lesson. Magnussen's pupils could examine, for example, living and dead rabbits from their breeding. Until 1964, essays in scientific journals were published by Magnussen. Magnussen retired in August 1970. Even in old age, Magnussen justified the Nazi racial ideology. She noted in 1980, in a conversation with the geneticist [[Benno Müller-Hill]], that the [[Nuremberg Laws]] were not fair enough. She also denied until the last minute that Mengele would have killed children for their scientific studies.Sascha Hönighaus: ''Karin Magnussen'', Berlin 2007, p. 199f. She was entangled by her cooperation with Mengele and the supply of "human material", and mired deep in concentration camp crimes, but she claimed to know nothing about them. In 1990, Magnussen moved into a nursing home; she died in February 1997 in Bremen. == Further reading == *Wolfgang Schieder, Achim Trunk: ''Adolf Butenandt and the Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gesellschaft''. Science, industry and politics in the Third Reich. Series: History of the Kaiser-Wilhelm Gesellschaft IM Nationalsozialismus, 7 Hg. Max Planck Society for the advancement of science, Wallenstein, Göttingen 2004, {{ISBN|978-3-89244-423-7}} *Hans Hesse: ''Eyes from Auschwitz. A lesson in National Socialist racial delusion and medical research. The case of Dr. Karin Magnussen'', plain text, Essen 2001, {{ISBN|3-89861-009-8}} *Sascha Hönighaus: "Karin Magnussen", in: Jessica Hoffman, Anja Megel, Robert Parzer & Helena Seidel eds.: ''Dahlemer Memorial locations'', Frank & Timme Verlag for scientific literature, Berlin 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-86596-144-0}} *Ernst Klee: ''the person lexicon to the Third Reich: who was what before and after 1945?'' Fischer, Frankfurt 2007, {{ISBN|3-596-16048-0}} DSB.: Auschwitz, NAZI medicine and its victims. 3rd Edition. S. Fischer, Frankfurt 1997, {{ISBN|3-596-14906-1}} *Carola Sachse Ed.: ''the link to Auschwitz. Life sciences and human experiments at Kaiser-Wilhelm-Instituts''. Documentation of a symposium. Wallenstein, Göttingen 2003 series: history of the Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gesellschaft IM Nationalsozialismus, 6. {{ISBN|3-89244-699-7}} (interim report see Web links) *Hans-Walter Schmuhl: Grenzüberschreitungen. ''Das Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Anthropologie, menschliche Erblehre und Eugenik 1927–1945. Reihe: Geschichte der Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gesellschaft im Nationalsozialismus'', 9. Wallstein, Göttingen 2005, {{ISBN|3-89244-799-3}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{DNB-Portal|123296129}} * [http://www.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/KWG/Ergebnisse/Ergebnisse3.pdf Online] Magnussen passim. {{Infobox religious building | building_name = Katskhi Pillar
კაცხის სვეტი | infobox_width = | image = Katskhi Pillar2 (edited).jpg | image_size = 275 px | alt = | caption = Katskhi Pillar | map_type = Georgia | map_size = 275 | location = [[Katskhi]], 5 km from the town of [[Chiatura]], [[Chiatura District]], [[Imereti]] Province ([[Mkhare]]), Georgia | coordinates = {{coord|42.2875|43.2156|display=inline,title}} | religious_affiliation = [[Georgian Orthodox Church]] | rite = | region = [[Caucasus]] | state = | province = | territory = | prefecture = | sector = | district = [[Argveti|Argveti District]] (historic)
[[Chiatura District]] (present) | cercle = | municipality = | consecration_year = | status = | functional_status = Abandoned (partially active since 1995), restored and rebuilt | heritage_designation = | leadership = The [[monk]] Maxim | website = | architecture = yes | architect = | architecture_type = Small church atop a stone pillar | architecture_style = [[Architecture of Georgia (country)|Georgian]]; [[Hermitage (religious retreat)|Hermitage]] and [[Monastery]] | founded_by = | funded_by = | general_contractor = | facade_direction = | groundbreaking = | year_completed = 9th or 10th century | construction_cost = | specifications = | capacity = | length = | width = | width_nave = | height_max = | dome_quantity = | dome_height_outer = | dome_height_inner = | dome_dia_outer = | dome_dia_inner = | minaret_quantity = | minaret_height = | spire_quantity = | spire_height = | materials = | nrhp = | added = | refnum = | designated = }} The '''Katskhi pillar''' ({{lang-ka|კაცხის სვეტი}}, ''kac'xis svet'i'') is a natural [[limestone]] [[monolith]] located at the village of [[Katskhi]] in western [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] [[mkhare|region]] of [[Imereti]], near the town of [[Chiatura]]. It is approximately {{convert|40|m|adj=off}} high, and overlooks the small river valley of Katskhura, a [[Tributary#Terminology|right affluent]] of the [[Qvirila River|Q'virila]].{{ka icon}} Gagoshidze, Giorgi (2010), [http://art.edu.ge/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/G_Gagoshidze1.pdf კაცხის სვეტი ("Katskhi Pillar")]. ''Academia'', No. '''1''': 55–68. ISSN 1512-0899. The rock, with visible church ruins on a top surface measuring {{circa}} 150 m2, has been venerated by locals as the Pillar of Life and a symbol of the [[True Cross]], and has become surrounded by legends. It remained unclimbed by researchers and unsurveyed until 1944 and was more systematically studied from 1999 to 2009. These studies determined the ruins were of an [[Early Middle Ages|early medieval]] [[hermitage (religious retreat)|hermitage]] dating from the 9th or 10th century. A [[Georgian alphabet|Georgian]] inscription [[paleography|paleographically]] dated to the 13th century suggests that the hermitage was still extant at that time. Religious activity associated with the pillar was revived in the 1990sBardzimashvili, Temo (August 27, 2010), [http://www.eurasianet.org/node/61812 Georgian Monk Builds Stairway to Heaven]. Eurasianet.org. Accessed May 12, 2012. and the monastery building had been restored within the framework of a state-funded program by 2009.[[National Agency for Cultural Heritage Preservation of Georgia]] (2009), [http://www.heritagesites.ge/files/PDF/Dzeglta%20reabilitacia.pdf Rehabilitation of the Monuments of Georgia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017231919/http://www.heritagesites.ge/files/PDF/Dzeglta%20reabilitacia.pdf |date=2013-10-17 }}, p. 142. Heritagesites.ge. Accessed May 12, 2012. == Architecture == The Katskhi pillar complex currently consists of a church dedicated to [[Maximus the Confessor]], a [[crypt]] ([[burial vault (tomb)|burial vault]]), three hermit cells, a wine cellar, and a [[curtain wall (fortification)|curtain wall]] on the uneven top surface of the column. At the base of the pillar are the newly built church of [[Simeon Stylites]] and ruins of an old wall and belfry.{{ka icon}} [http://www.dzeglebi.ge/dzeglebi/k/kacxis_sveti.html კაცხის სვეტი ("Katskhi Pillar")]. Dzeglebi.ge. Accessed May 12, 2012. The church of St. Maximus the Confessor is located at the south-easternmost corner of the top surface of the Katskhi pillar. A small simple [[hall church]] design with the dimensions of 4.5 × 3.5 m., it is a modern restoration of the ruined medieval church built of stone. Beneath and south of the church is an elongated rectangular crypt with the dimensions of 2.0 × 1.0 m., which had served as a burial vault. Digs at the ruined wine cellar revealed eight large vessels known in Georgia as ''k'vevri''. Also of note is a rectangular cellar grotto with the entrance and two skylights—on the vertical surface of the rock, some {{convert|10|m|adj=on}} below the top. At the very base of the pillar there is a cross in relief, exhibiting parallels with similar early medieval depictions found elsewhere in Georgia, particularly at [[Bolnisi cross|Bolnisi]]. == History == [[File:Katskhi stone column (G.N. 2009).jpg|thumb|left|The Katskhi pillar in 2009.]] In historical records, the Katskhi pillar is first mentioned by the 18th-century Georgian scholar Prince [[Vakhushti]], who reports in his ''Geographic Description of the Kingdom of Georgia'': "There is a rock within the ravine standing like a pillar, considerably high. There is a small church on the top of the rock, but nobody is able to ascend it; nor know they how to do that."{{ka icon}} {{fr icon}} Wakhoucht ([[Marie-Félicité Brosset|Brosset, Marie-Félicité]], transl., 1842) [https://books.google.ge/books?ei=n36uT4H3M9DotQaQ7enNBg&id=mkkEAAAAYAAJ&dq=description+geographique+de+la+georgie&q=Catzkh#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Description géographique de la Géorgie''], pp. 365–369. St. Petersbourg: A la typographie de l'Academie Impériale des Sciences.[[W.E.D. Allen|Allen, W.E.D.]] (1950). "Two Georgian Maps of the First Half of the Eighteenth Century". ''Imago Mundi'', Vol. 10: 109-110. No other written accounts of monastic life or ascents survive. A number of local legends surround the pillar. One of them has it that the top of the rock was connected by a long iron chain to the dome of the [[Katskhi monastery|Katskhi church]], located at a distance of around 1.5 km from the pillar. In July 1944 a group led by the mountaineer Alexander Japaridze and the writer [[Levan Gotua]] made the first documented ascent of the Katskhi pillar. Vakhtang Tsintsadze, an architecture specialist with the group, reported in his 1946 paper that the ruins found on top of the rock were remains of two churches, dating from the 5th and 6th centuries and associated with a [[stylites|stylite]] practice, a form of Christian [[asceticism]]. Since 1999, the Katskhi pillar has become the subject of more systematic research. Based on further studies and archaeological digs conducted in 2006, Giorgi Gagoshidze, an art historian with the [[Georgian National Museum]], re-dated the structures to the 9th–10th century. He concluded that this complex was composed of a monastery church and cells for hermits. Discovery of the remnants of a wine cellar also undermined the idea of extreme ascetism flourishing on the pillar. In 2007, a small limestone plate with the ''[[asomtavruli]]'' Georgian inscriptions was found, paleographically dated to the 13th century and revealing the name of a certain "Giorgi", responsible for the construction of three hermit cells. The inscription also makes mention of the Pillar of Life, echoing the popular tradition of veneration of the rock as a symbol of the True Cross. Religious activity started to revive in 1995, with the arrival of the monk Maxim Qavtaradze, a native of Chiatura.{{cite news|last=Day|first=Matthew|title=The monk who lives up a rock to get closer to God|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/georgia/10291740/The-monk-who-lives-up-a-rock-to-get-closer-to-God.html|accessdate=7 September 2013|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=6 September 2013|location=[[London]]}} Between 2005 and 2009, the monastery building on the top of the pillar was restored with the support of the [[National Agency for Cultural Heritage Preservation of Georgia]]. The rock was once accessible to male visitors through an iron ladder running from its base to the top, but has recently been deemed inaccessible to the public. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category|Katskhi pillar}} {{Georgian Churches}} [[Category:Natural monoliths]] [[Category:Georgian Orthodox monasteries]] [[Category:Geography of Imereti]] [[Category:Stylites]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Imereti]] [[Category:Immovable Cultural Monuments of National Significance of Georgia]]

revision.text:
'''[[French Argentines]]''' are Argentines of full or partial [[French people|French descent]], or French-born people who reside in Argentina. Most of French immigrants settled in Argentina from the 1870s until WW1, though consistent immigration started in the 1820s and continued until the late 1940s. Half of these immigrants came from Southwestern France, especially from the [[Northern Basque Country|Basque Country]] and [[Béarn]] (former [[Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Basses-Pyrénées]] accounted for more than 20% of immigrants), as well as [[Bigorre]] and [[Rouergue]], but also from [[Savoy]] and the [[Paris]] region. As early as in the 1840s, Argentina also received immigrants with French background from neighboring countries, notably [[French Uruguayans|Uruguay]]. In 2006, it was estimated that around 6 million Argentines had some degree of French ancestry (up to 17% of the total population).

Larralde, born in France.}}</ref> *[[Alfredo Fortabat]], founder of [[Loma Negra]], born to French parents<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Alfredo-Fortabat-Pourtale/6000000000541153789 ===Public figures=== *[[María Lorenza Barreneche]], First Lady of Argentina from 1983 to 1989, with distant French ancestry through her maternal great-grandfather<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.genealogiafamiliar.net/getperson.php?personID=I603319&tree=BVCZ |title=María Lorenza Barreneche Iriarte |quote=Great-ganddaughter of Francisco Hospital Camou, born in France in 1831.}}</ref> *[[:es:Silvia Martorell|Silvia Martorell]], First Lady of Argentina from 1963 to 1966, with distant French ancestry through her paternal great-grandfather<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Silvia-Martorell-Kaswalder/6000000002156313086 |title=Silvia Elvira Martorell Kaswalder |quote=Great-granddaughter of Juan Lafourcade Arguindegui, born in France.}}</ref> *[[Queen Máxima of the Netherlands]], queen consort of the Netherlands, with remote French ancestry through her maternal great-great-parents<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rfgenealogie.com/s-informer/infos/celebrites/genealogie-et-parentes-du-roi-willem-alexander |title=Généalogie et parentés du roi Willem-Alexander |quote=Née à Buenos-Aires, Maxima Zorreguieta Cerruti est fille de Maria del Carmen Cerruti Carricart (1944), elle-même fille de Maria del Carmen Carricart Cieza (1915-1999), fille à son tour de Domingo Carricart Etchart (1885-1953). Ce dernier, arrière-grand-père de la reine, était le fils d’un vétérinaire basque français, Bernard Carricart, qui avait émigré en 1865 en Argentine. Un arrière arrière-grand-père né à Moncayolle, dans les Basses-Pyrénées.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://heinbruins.nl/Maxima.html |title=Ancestors of Máxima Zorreguieta Cerruti |quote=Bernardo CARRICART HARAMBURU emigrated with his wife (Juana ETCHART IRIART) to Argentina in 1865.}}</ref> *[[Pilar Nores de García]], twice First Lady of Peru from 1985 to 1990, and from 2006 to 2011, with distant French ancestry through her maternal great-grandparents<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gw.geneanet.org/gentuc?lang=en&n=nores+bodereau&oc=0&p=maria+del+pilar |title=María del Pilar Nores Bodereau |quote=Great-granddaughter of Aureliano Bodereau and Catalina Picarel, born in France.}}</ref> *[[Eva Perón]], First Lady of Argentina from 1946 to 1952, with French ancestry through her paternal grandparents<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Maria-Eva-Duarte-Ibarguren/4683792416130122024 |title=María Eva Duarte Ibarguren |quote=Granddaughter of Francisco Duarte (Huart) and María Etchegoyen, born in France in 1817 and 1823.}}</ref>

==Visual arts==
===Architects=== *[[Pedro Benoit]], architect, born to French father<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gw.geneanet.org/markos1?lang=en&n=benoit+leyes&oc=0&p=pedro+simon+del+corazon+de+jesus |title=Pedro Simón del Corazón de Jesús Benoit Leyes |quote=Son of Pierre Benoît Daut, born in France.}}</ref> *[[:es:Pierre Benoît|Pierre Benoît]], French-born achitect *[[:es:Próspero Catelin|Próspero Catelin]], French-born architect and engineer *[[:es:León Dourge|León Dourge]], French-born architect who designed the [[Palacio Duhau - Park Hyatt Buenos Aires|Palacio Duhau]] *[[:es:Louis Dubois|Louis Dubois]], French-born architect and painter *[[:es:Arturo Dubourg|Arturo Dubourg]], architect *[[:es:Jorge Ferrari Hardoy|Jorge Ferrari Hardoy]], architect and designer *[[Eduardo Le Monnier]], French-born architect *[[:es:Carlos Malbranche|Carlos Malbranche]], architect, born to French parents<ref>{{cite web |url=https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Malbranche |title=Carlos Malbranche |quote=Sus padres: Gustave Gabriel Edouard Malbranche Bourdon, nacido en París, el 29/3/1860; Marie-Marthe Gréteau Jarris, nacida en Queyrac, Gironde, el 2/10/1861, casados en Buenos Aires hacia 1885.}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=May 2018}} *[[Patricio Pouchulu]], architect
===Comic book artists=== *[[Louis Cazeneuve]], comic book artist *[[Liniers (cartoonist)|Liniers]], cartoonist<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parlamentario.com/noticia-74579.html |title=La Legislatura porteña homenajeará a Ricardo Siri Liniers |quote=Descendiente del virrey Santiago de Liniers.}}</ref> *[[Carlos Loiseau|Caloi]], cartoonist<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.petitherge.com/article-carlos-loiseau-dit-caloi-110769270.html |title=Carlos Loiseau dit Caloi |quote=Carlos Loiseau est né à Salta le 9 novembre 1948, de parents d’origine française, belge, suisse, italienne.}}</ref> *[[:es:Carlos Roume|Carlos Roume]], cartoonist, born to French father<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nacionalypopular.com/2009/09/26/roume-no-discutia-con-dios/ |title=Roume no discutía con Dios |quote=Era el noveno hijo del arquitecto ornamental y escultor francés François Roume.}}</ref> *[[:es:Tute (humorista)|Tute]], cartoonist, son of Caloi<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lanacion.com.ar/1050534-tute-lios-de-pareja |title=Tute, líos de pareja |quote=Hijo de Caloi, humorista gráfico.}}</ref>
===Painters=== *[[Numa Ayrinhac]], French-born painter *[[Norma Bessouet]], painter *[[:es:Ernest Charton|Ernest Charton]], French-born painter *[[Gustavo Cochet]], painter, born to French father<ref>{{cite web |url=http://museocochet.blogspot.fr/2010/05/lunes-14-de-noviembre-de-2005-uno-hace.html |title=Gustavo Cochet |quote=Nació en Rosario, el mayor de 6 hijos que tuviera Don Víctor Cochet, venido de Francia.}}</ref> *[[Julio Ducuron]], painter, with French ancestry through his paternal grandfather<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gw.geneanet.org/ducuron?lang=en&p=julio+eduardo&n=ducuron |title=Julio Eduardo Ducuron |quote=Grandson of Joseph Jean Marie Ducuron, born in France in 1878.}}</ref> *[[Fernando Fader]], French-born painter *[[:es:Amadeo Gras|Amadeo Gras]], French-born painter *[[Julio Le Parc]], painter and sculptor, with French ancestry through his paternal grandfather<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lanacion.com.ar/1899476-julio-le-parc-jamas-hablo-de-obras-de-arte-las-llamo-experiencias |title=Julio Le Parc: "Jamás hablo de obras de arte, las llamo experiencias..." |quote=“Podría ser la larga marcha de mi abuelo, que vino del norte de Francia a París, atravesó el Atlántico, llegó aquí, tomó un tren y cuando las vías se terminaron se bajó en el pueblo de Rivadavia, en Mendoza.”}}</ref> *[[:es:Miguel Ocampo|Miguel Ocampo]], painter, with remote French ancestry through his maternal great-great-grandfather<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Miguel-Ocampo-Leloir/6000000011660806811 |title=Miguel Ocampo Leloir |quote=Great-great-grandson of Antonio Francisco Leloir Capdepont, born in France in 1786; Great-great-great-great-grandson of Juan Martín Pedro Pueyrredón Labroucherie, born in France in 1738.}}</ref> *[[Charles Pellegrini]], French-born painter and engineer *[[Prilidiano Pueyrredón]], painter, architect, and engineer, with French ancestry through his paternal grandfather<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Prilidiano-Pueyrredon/6000000000076361207 |title=Prilidiano Pueyrredón Tellechea |quote=Grandson of Juan Martín Pedro Pueyrredón Labroucherie, born in France in 1738.}}</ref> *[[Guillermo Roux]], painter, born to French Uruguayan father
===Other visual artists=== *[[Adolfo Bellocq]], printmaker *[[:es:Alfonso Fermepin|Alfonso Fermepin]], French-born photographer *[[Esteban Gonnet]], French-born photographer *[[Carlos Thays]], French-born landscape architect
==Other== *[[:es:Jeannette Arata de Erize|Jeannette Arata de Erize]], president of [[Mozarteum Argentino]], with French ancestry through her mother's line<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lanacion.com.ar/1608707-fallecio-jeannette-arata-de-erize-artifice-del-mozarteum-argentino |title=Murió Jeannette Arata de Erize, artífice del Mozarteum Argentino |quote=Era hija del cirujano argentino Dr. Luis Aratamadre y de Valentina Ruftz de Lavinson, descendiente de una familia de la nobleza francesa.}}</ref> *[[:es:Federico Biraben|Federico Biraben]], librarian who promoted the use of the [[Universal Decimal Classification]] in Argentina, born in Uruguay to French parents<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Ferderico-Biraben/6000000011799598673 |title=Federico Biraben |quote=Son of Alfredo Biraben and Stephanie Flürer, both born in France.}}</ref> *[[Jorge Romero Brest]], art critic, with French ancestry through his maternal grandmother<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.archivoromerobrest.com.ar/indice/autobiografia.htm |title=A Damián Carlos Bayón, discípulo y amigo |quote=Mi abuela materna era francesa.}}</ref> *[[:es:Abel Cháneton|Abel Cháneton]], historian *[[Matilde Díaz Vélez]], urbanist and philanthropist, with French ancestry through her maternal grandmother<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gw.geneanet.org/gentuc?lang=en&p=matilde&n=diaz+velez+y+alvarez+de+toledo |title=Matilde Díaz Vérez y Álvarez de Toledo |quote=Granddaughter of María Antonieta “Antoinette” Faix Salesse, born in France in 1850.}}</ref> *[[Gato Dumas]], chef, with distant French ancestry through both lines of his family<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.genealogiafamiliar.net/getperson.php?personID=I620386&tree=BVCZ |title=Carlos Alberto Dumas Lagos |quote=(Father's line) Great-grandson of Juan (or Jean) Dumas and Dominga Etchevers, most likely born in France; (Mother's line—born in France to Argentine parents) Great-great-great-grandson of Augusto Dejean Trei, born in France in 1801.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://gw.geneanet.org/markos1?lang=fr&pz=marcos+juan&nz=belgrano+lagache&ocz=0&p=jeanne+therese&n=dumas+etchevers |title=Jeanne Thérèse Dumas Etchevers |quote=As she carried French first and middle names (Jeanne Thérèse), the elder sister of his grandfather, Federico Dumas Etchevers, was probably born in France, prior to the immigration of the family to Argentina.}}</ref> *[[:es:Christophe Krywonis|Christophe Krywonis]], French-born chef *[[Anna Larroucau Laborde de Lucero]], French-born educator and philanthropist *[[Augusto S. Mallié]], historian and director of the [[General Archive of the Nation (Argentina)|National General Archive]], born to French father and French Argentine mother<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Augusto-Mallie-Rouquaud/6000000037658443265 |title=Augusto Mallié Rouquaud |quote=Son of Augusto Mallié, born in France in 1827; (Mother's line) Grandson of Ernesto Rouquaud Kinton and María Luisa Périchon, born in France in 1821 and 1825.}}</ref> *[[Camila O'Gorman]], 19th century socialite, with French ancestry through her paternal grandmother<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.genealogiafamiliar.net/getperson.php?personID=I28881&tree=BVCZ |title=María Camila O'Gorman Ximénez |quote=Granddaughter of María Ana Perichon de Vandeuil d'Abeille, born in France in 1775.}}</ref> *[[Marie Anne Périchon de Vandeuil]], French-born 19th century socialite, known to be the mistress of viceroy Santiago de Liniers *[[:es:Jean Sère|Jean Sère]], French-born landowner *[[:es:José Gabriel Vazeilles|José Gabriel Vazeilles]], historian
==See also== *[[French Argentine|French immigration to Argentina]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

page.title: List of ambulance drivers during World War I

revision.text:
This is a list of notable people who served as ambulance drivers during the First World War. A remarkable number—writers especially—volunteered as [[ambulance]] drivers for the [[Allies of World War I|Allied Powers]]. In many cases, they sympathized strongly with the ideals of the Allied Powers, but did not want, or were too young or old, to participate in a combat role. For women, combat was not an option at the time. Several of the Americans on the list volunteered before the United States' 1917 entry into the war. Many of the American writers would later be associated with the [[Lost Generation]].
==Businessmen== *[[Tony Hulman]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Indianapolis Star |first= |title=The Hulman Family |url=http://www2.indystar.com/library/factfiles/people/h/hulman_family/hulman_anton.html |work=The Indianapolis Star |publisher=Gannett Co. Inc. |date=11 April 2001 |accessdate=27 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710181822/http://www2.indystar.com/library/factfiles/people/h/hulman_family/hulman_anton.html |archivedate=10 July 2012 |df= }}</ref> – American businessman, owner and operator of [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]], and volunteer with the [[American Red Cross]] *[[Ray Kroc]] – American entrepreneur of [[McDonald's Corporation]] fame – trained to become an ambulance driver, though the war ended before he saw action.
==Composers==
*[[Maurice Ravel]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Biography |first= |title=Maurice Ravel Biography |url=http://www.8notes.com/biographies/ravel.asp |work=Maurice Ravel |publisher=8notes.com |date=|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> – volunteer ambulance driver or truck driver *[[Albert Roussel]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Wright |first=David C.F |title=Albert Roussel |url=http://www.wrightmusic.net/pdfs/albert-roussel.pdf |work=Albert Roussel |publisher=wrightmusic.net |year=2002|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> – [[Red Cross]] transport driver *[[Ralph Vaughan Williams]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Documents Online |first= |title=Famous names in the First World War – Ralph Vaughan Williams |url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/documentsonline/medals-vaughanwilliams.asp |work=The National Archives |publisher=The National Archives |date=2001–2004|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> – [[Royal Army Medical Corps]]
==Filmmakers== *[[René Clair]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Amengual |first=Barthélemy |title=René Clair |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/119594/Rene-Clair |work=the Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=the Encyclopædia Britannica |date=|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> *[[Jean Cocteau]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Fowlie |first=Wallace |title=Jean Cocteau |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/123832/Jean-Cocteau |work=the Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=the Encyclopædia Britannica |date=|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> *[[Walt Disney]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/world-war-one-walt |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027004057/http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/world-war-one-walt |archivedate=2014-10-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/over-there-walt-disneys-world-war-i-adventure |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027005802/http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/over-there-walt-disneys-world-war-i-adventure |archivedate=2014-10-27 |df= }}</ref> – volunteer [[American Red Cross]], but served after the armistice ending World War I was signed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/american-flag |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027010151/http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/american-flag |archivedate=2014-10-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/national-world-war-i-museums-ford-ambulance-kansas-city |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027005750/http://www.waltdisney.org/storyboard/national-world-war-i-museums-ford-ambulance-kansas-city |archivedate=2014-10-27 |df= }}</ref> *[[William A. Wellman]]<ref>Silke, James R. "Fists, Dames & Wings." ''Air Progress Aviation Review'', Volume 4, No. 4, October 1980.</ref>
==Writers==
*[[Robert C. Binkley]] – volunteer, [[United States Army Ambulance Service]] *[[Louis Bromfield]]<ref name="Carr">Carr, Virginia. ''Dos Passos – A Life''. Doubleday, 1984, p. 127.</ref> – volunteer [[American Field Service]] *[[William Slater Brown]]<ref name="Carr" /> – volunteer [[American Volunteer Motor Ambulance Corps|Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps]] *[[Malcolm Cowley]]<ref name="Carr" /> – volunteer [[American Field Service]] *[[Harry Crosby]]<ref name="Carr" /> – volunteer [[American Field Service]] *[[E. E. Cummings]]<ref name="Carr" /> – volunteer [[American Volunteer Motor Ambulance Corps|Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps]] *[[Kati Dadeshkeliani]] – [[Imperial Russian Army|Russian Army]] ambulance driver *[[Russell Davenport]]<ref name="Ruediger" /> – [[U.S. Army Medical Corps]] *[[John Dos Passos]]<ref>{{cite web | last = Carr | first = Virginia | title = Dos Passos in the Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps | url = http://www.ourstory.info/library/2-ww1/DosPassos.html | website= Our Story | year = 1984 | accessdate = June 13, 2012 }}</ref> – volunteer [[American Volunteer Motor Ambulance Corps|Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps]] *[[Dale Van Every]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Bradley |first=Edwin M. |date=2004 |title=The First Hollywood Musicals: A Critical Filmography of 171 Features, 1927 through 1932 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rg-UBJaPD-sC&lpg=PA124&dq=dale%20van%20every%20ambulance&pg=PA124#v=onepage&q=dale%20van%20every%20ambulance&f=false |location=Jefferson, NC |publisher=McFarland |page=124 |isbn=9780786420292 |accessdate=2014-07-21 }}</ref> – volunteer, [[United States Army Ambulance Service]] *[[Julien Green]]<ref name="Carr" /><ref>{{cite web|last= |first= |title= Julien Green (1900-1998)|url=http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-529 |work=The New Georgia Encyclopedia|publisher= the Georgia Humanities Council and the University of Georgia Press |accessdate=15 June 2012}}</ref>- volunteer [[American Field Service]] *[[Ernest Hemingway]]<ref name="Carr" /> – volunteer American Red Cross in Italy *[[Robert Hillyer]]<ref name="Carr" /> – volunteer [[American Volunteer Motor Ambulance Corps|Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps]] *[[Sidney Howard]]<ref name="Carr" /> – volunteer [[American Field Service]] *[[Jerome K. Jerome]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Steven |first=Andrew |title=Jerome K Jerome the man |url=http://www.jeromekjerome.com/About_Jerome/the_man |work=The Jerome K Jerome Society |publisher=The Jerome K Jerome Society |date=2009–2012 |accessdate=22 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211153734/http://www.jeromekjerome.com/About_Jerome/the_man |archivedate=11 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> – [[French Army]] ambulance driver *[[John Howard Lawson]]<ref>Carr, Virginia. ''Dos Passos – A Life''. Doubleday, 1984, p. 124.</ref> – volunteer [[American Volunteer Motor Ambulance Corps|Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps]] *[[Desmond MacCarthy]]<ref name="Ruediger" /> – volunteer [[British Red Cross]] ambulance corps *[[Archibald MacLeish]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Poets.org |first= |title=Archibald MacLeish|url=http://www.poets.org/poet.php/prmPID/47 |work=Poets.org|publisher=Academy of American Poets |date= 1997–2012|accessdate=21 June 2012}}</ref> – [[U.S. Army]] ambulance driver, who later became an artillery captain *[[John Masefield]] – served as hospital orderly in British hospital for French soldiers in France *[[F. Van Wyck Mason]]<ref>Dictionary of American Biography, Supplement 10: 1976-1980. Charles Scribner's Sons, 1995.</ref> – ambulance corps volunteer, who later joined the [[French Army]] and then the U.S. Army. Grandfather Frank H. Mason was Chairman of the Ambulance Committee of the American Hospital in Paris.<ref>{{cite web|last=American Committee |first= |title=American Hospital In Paris Annual Report 1915|url=http://www.ourstory.info/library/2-ww1/AmHosp15/ahp1915.html |work=\|publisher= |date= 31 August 1915|accessdate=31 December 2015}}</ref> *[[Somerset Maugham]]<ref name="Ruediger" /> – volunteer [[British Red Cross]] ambulance corps *[[Charles Nordhoff]]<ref name="Ruediger" /> – volunteer [[American Field Service]] *[[William Seabrook]]<ref name="Carr" /><ref name="Ruediger">{{cite web|last= Ruediger |first= Steve |title= Literary Ambulance Drivers |url= http://www.firstworldwar.com/poetsandprose/ambulance.htm |work= firstworldwar.com |publisher= firstworldwar.com |date= 22 August 2009|accessdate=17 June 2012}}</ref> – [[American Field Service]] *[[Robert W. Service]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Webmaster |first= |title=Biography:|url=http://www.robertwservice.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=3 |work=Robert W Service, The Original Homepage|publisher=RobertWService.com |date= 21 July 2003|accessdate=21 June 2012}}</ref> – [[British Red Cross]] volunteer *[[Olaf Stapledon]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Gilster |first=Paul |title=Star Maker: The Philosophy of Olaf Stapledon|url=http://www.centauri-dreams.org/?p=20746 |work=Centauri Dreams – The News Forum of the Tau Zero Foundation|publisher=the Tau Zero Foundation |date= 28 November 2011|accessdate=21 June 2012}}</ref> – [[Friends' Ambulance Unit]] volunteer * [[Gertrude Stein]] - volunteer in France *[[Hugh Walpole]] – [[Red Cross]] volunteer in Russia *[[Amos Wilder|Amos Niven Wilder]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Robertson |first=Hamish |title=Amos Niven Wilder (1895-1993), Brother |url=http://www.thorntonwilder.com/amos-niven-wilder-1895-1993-brother.html |work=the Official Website of The Thornton Wilder Family |publisher=The Wilder Family LLC |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=21 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423011838/http://www.thorntonwilder.com/amos-niven-wilder-1895-1993-brother.html |archivedate=23 April 2012 |df= }}</ref> – [[American Field Service]] volunteer, who later joined an artillery unit
==Other notable people== *[[Frank Buckles]]<ref>{{cite web | website= frankbuckles.org | first = | title = Frank W. Buckles – America's Last Survivor of the First World War | url = http://www.frankbuckles.org/ | | date = 15 June 2012 | accessdate = June 15, 2012 }}</ref> – Last American World War I veteran *[[Marion Barbara "Joe" Carstairs]] – wealthy British power boat racer known for her speed and her eccentric lifestyle<ref>{{cite web|last=Book Description |first= |title=Book Description of The Queen of Whale Cay: The Eccentric Story of "Joe" Carstairs, Fastest Woman on Water by Kate Summerscale|url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Queen-Whale-Cay-ebook/dp/B007N6JDXO/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1340380654&sr=8-6&keywords=kate+summerscale |work=Amazon.com |publisher=Amazon.com |date=22 May 2012|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> *[[Stafford Cripps]] – British politician *[[Hélène Dutrieu]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Cooper |first=Ralph |title=HÉLÉNE DUTRIEU 1877-1961 AKA Héléne Dutrieux |url=http://www.earlyaviators.com/edutrieu.htm |work=earlyaviators.com|publisher=earlyaviators.com |date=|accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> – pioneering French [[aviator]] *[[Florence Jaffray Harriman]] – socialite and member of Wilson's commission on labor unrest – director of the Women's Motor Corps in France, and organizer of the [[American Red Cross]] Women's Motor Corps of the District of Columbia *[[Cathleen Mann]] - British artist *[[Olive Mudie-Cooke]] - British artist *[[Waldo Peirce]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Gallagher|first=William|title=Waldo Peirce – Brief life of a vibrant artist: 1884-1970|url=http://harvardmagazine.com/2002/01/waldo-peirce.html|work=Harvard Magazine|publisher=Harvard Magazine Inc.|accessdate=15 June 2012}}</ref> – American painter – volunteer [[American Field Service]] *[[Alice B. Toklas]] - American member of the Parisian avant-garde of the early 20th century, and the life partner of Gertrude Stein *[[Percy Toplis]] – notorious British deserter
==People who served the Allies in a related capacity==
*[[Algernon Blackwood]] – [[British Red Cross]] Searcher, trying to identify dead or lost soldiers – British author *[[A.J. Cronin]] – [[Royal Navy]] [[surgeon]] – [[List of Scottish novelists|Scottish novelist]] *[[Teilhard de Chardin|Fr. Teilhard de Chardin, SJ]] - French stretcher bearer - Jesuit priest, paleontologist, geologist, theologian, author *Fr. Angelo Giuseppe Roncalli – stretcher carrier and chaplain in Italian Army – later elected [[Pope John XXIII]] *[[Marjory Stoneman Douglas]] – [[American Red Cross]] volunteer – eminent American [[conservation movement|conservationist]] *[[Dorothy Canfield Fisher]] – volunteered to help blinded Allied soldiers – American social activist and author *[[E.M. Forster]] – interviewed wounded in [[Egypt]]ian hospitals – English novelist *[[Peter Grant (footballer, born 1879)|Peter Grant]] – volunteer driver/mechanic<ref name="McCrossan">{{cite web|url=http://www.queensparkfc.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Appendix-2.pdf|title=The Queen's Park Men Who Served And Survived As At October 2016 – Appendix 2|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|page=6|accessdate=22 October 2016}}</ref> *[[Anne Green]] – volunteer work, author and translator – sister of aforementioned ambulance driver and author Julian Green *[[Frederick Leney]] - British Red Cross Searcher, 1914–1916. *[[Alexander H. Rice, Jr.]] - volunteer physician, explorer in South America *[[Gertrude Stein]] – volunteer driver for French hospitals – American poet, [[playwright]], [[feminist]] *[[Edmund Wilson]] – American literary critic
== References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ambulance Drivers During World War I}} [[Category:World War I-related lists|Ambulance drivers]] [[Category:Military medicine in World War I]] [[Category:Lists of people by activity|Ambulance drivers during World War I]]

revision.comment: /* Death */ ideas for expansion of section

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |honorific_prefix= [[Major]] |name=M. C. Muthanna |honorific_suffix=[[Shaurya Chakra]] |image = MangeriraChinnappaMuthannaPic.jpg |caption = |birth_date=21 April 1964 |death_date={{death date and age|2000|1|12|1964|4|21}} |birth_place= Chettimani, Bhagamandala, [[Kodagu]] district, Karnataka |caste= [[Kodava]] |death_place= [[Ananthnag]], [[Jammu and Kashmir]] |placeofburial= |nickname= |allegiance= {{flag|India}} |branch=[[Indian Army]] |serviceyears= |rank= Major |unit= |commands= |battles= |awards= |relations= |laterwork= }} Major '''Mangerira Chinnappa Muthanna''' was a war hero of India.
==Early life== Mangerira Chinnappa Muthanna was born in Chettimani village (near [[Bhagamandala]]), [[Kodagu]] district (Coorg) on 21 April 1964.
==Army Service== He joined OTA, Chennai in Oct 1984 and was commissioned into the 5th Battalion the Sikh Light Infantry on 24th Oct 1985. He served the 5 Sikh Light Infantry-Hq 1 Sector [[Rashtriya Rifles]]. He died on January 12, 2000, aged 36 years, while fighting with terrorists of [[Lashkar-e-Taiba|Lashker-e-Toiba]] (LeT) in [[Ananthnag]], [[Jammu and Kashmir]].
==Posthumous honour== He was awarded with the [[Shaurya Chakra]] posthumously.<ref>{{cite web|title=School and Road, in memory of a Martyr|url=http://www.coorg.com/school-and-road-in-memory-of-a-martyr/|publisher=Coorg.com|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> To commemorate him, a statue of the martyr was unveiled in front of the Madikeri City Municipal Council (CMC) Hall and Kodagu named the municipal circle in front of Cauvery Kalakshethra (Town Hall) after him on Thursday, December 9, 2000. This became the fourth traffic junction in Madikeri that was named after a hero. The statue, made of granite stone, was sculpted at a cost of Rs. 8 lakh by sculptor Manjunath Acharya of Beetikatte in [[Somwarpet]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Brave heart’s statue to be unveiled on Dec. 9|url=http://www.coorg.com/brave-hearts-statue-to-be-unveiled-on-dec-9/|publisher=Coorg.com|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> In [[Khanbal]] district of [[Jammu and Kashmir]], the [[Indian Army]] named a road, a recreation hall and a school after Major Muthanna.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dinesh|first=B C|title=Dedicated to nation’s defence|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/karnataka/article172390.ece?service=print|accessdate=16 April 2014|date=Dec 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Correspondent|first=Staff|title=Statue to be installed for Muthanna|url=http://www.hindu.com/2010/11/22/stories/2010112260350300.htm|accessdate=16 April 2014|date=Nov 22, 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Muthanna, Mangerira Chinnappa}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:Indian Army officers]] [[Category:Recipients of the Shaurya Chakra]] [[Category:Kodava people]] [[Category:People from Kodagu district]] [[Category:Indian military personnel killed in action]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox academic | name = Marcia Ochoa | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Marciaochoa.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Marcia Ochoa | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1970|9|9}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!--{{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|1967|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date)--> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline, title}}--> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = | workplaces = [[University of California, Santa Cruz]] [[Stanford University]] | topics = | education = | alma_mater = [[Stanford University]] <small>(Ph.D.)</small><ref>{{Cite book |last= Asencio |first= Marysol |date=2009 |title=Latina/o Sexualities: Probing Powers, Passions, Practices, and Policies |url= |location=Rutgers, NJ |publisher=Rutgers University Press |page= |isbn= |author-link= }}</ref>| thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = Purnima Mankekar | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Latino Studies]], [[Transgender studies]], [[Queer theory]], [[Ethnography]], "Perverse Citizenship"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ochoa|first=Marcia|date=2008-12-14|title=Perverse Citizenship: Divas, Marginality, and Participation in "Loca-Lization"|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/255366|journal=WSQ: Women's Studies Quarterly|volume=36|issue=3|pages=146–169|doi=10.1353/wsq.0.0102|issn=1934-1520}}</ref> | influences =
| influenced = | awards = | spouse = <!--(or | spouses = )--> | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Marcia Ochoa''' (born 9 September 1970) is a United States-based professor of [[Feminist Studies]] and Critical Race and Ethnic Studies at the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://lals.ucsc.edu/faculty/singleton.php?&singleton=true&cruz_id=marcia8a|title=Marcia Ochoa|last=|first=|date=|website=lals.ucsc.edu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> She is the co-founder of [[El/La Para TransLatinas]] and is credited with popularizing the term "translatina."<ref>Miguel, Yolanda Martínez-San, and Sarah Tobias. Trans Studies: The Challenge to Hetero/Homo Normativities. Rutgers University Press, 2016.</ref>
== Life == Ochoa moved to San Francisco in 1994.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.queeroutlook.org/portfolio/marcia-ochoa/|title=Marcia Ochoa {{!}} OUT/LOOK & the Birth of the Queer|work=OUT/LOOK & the Birth of the Queer|access-date=2018-01-13|language=en-US}}</ref> She co-founded [[El/La Para TransLatinas]] in 2006 in [[San Francisco]], California.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ellaparatranslatinas.yolasite.com/contact-us.php|title=El/La Para TransLatinas|website=ellaparatranslatinas.yolasite.com|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
== Career == Ochoa completed her Ph.D. at Stanford University in Anthropology in 2005.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Ochoa |first=Marcia |date=2014 |title=Queen for a day: Transformistas, Misses and Mass Media in Venezuela |url= |location=Stanford, CA |publisher=Stanford University |page= |isbn= |author-link= }}</ref> She began teaching at the University of California, Santa Cruz in 2012, where she chairs the Feminist Studies department. She is also a professor of Critical Race and Ethnic Studies, Anthropology, Latin American & Latino Studies, and Film and Digital Media.<ref name=":0" />
She published her first book based on her dissertation, ''Queen for a Day: Transformistas, Beauty Queens and the Performance of Femininity in Venezuela'', in 2014 through [[Duke University Press]].<ref>{{Cite book |last=Ochoa |first=Marcia |date=2014 |title=Queen for a Day: Transformistas, Beauty Queens, and the Performance of Femininity in Venezuela |url= |location=Durham, NC |publisher=Duke University Press |page= |isbn= |author-link= }}</ref> It was nominated for a [[Lambda Literary Award]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-lambda-literary-awards-20150602-story.html|title=Lambda Literary Awards laud best gay, lesbian and transgender books|last=Kellogg|first=Carolyn|date=2015-06-02|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-01-13|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> That same year, she edited the [[Transgender Studies Quarterly]] issue "Decolonizing the Transgender Imaginary".<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Decolonizing-Transgender-Imaginary-Studies-Quarterly/dp/082236817X/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1513115971&sr=1-3&keywords=Marcia+Ochoa</ref> She is currently the editor of [[GLQ: A Journal of Lesbian and Gay Studies]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://read.dukeupress.edu/glq|title=GLQ {{!}} Duke University Press|website=read.dukeupress.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dukeupress.wordpress.com/2015/06/25/interview-marcia-ochoa-future-glq/|title=An Interview with Marcia Ochoa: How She Envisions the Future of GLQ|date=2015-06-25|work=Duke University Press News|access-date=2018-01-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
Following the publication of ''Queen for a Day'', Ochoa's work focused on early colonial violence in [[Latin America]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.colorado.edu/genders/2016/05/19/los-huecos-negros-cannibalism-sodomy-and-failure-modernity-tierra-firme|title=Los Huecos Negros: Cannibalism, Sodomy and the Failure of Modernity in Tierra Firme {{!}} Genders {{!}} University of Colorado Boulder|website=www.colorado.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ochoa, Marcia}} [[Category:Feminist studies scholars]] [[Category:University of California, Santa Cruz faculty]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Academic journal editors]] [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:Living people]]
