{{Infobox person | name = Maura Rivera | image = | caption = | birth_name = Maura Verónica Rivera Díaz | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1984|12|18|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Santiago, Chile]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = Dancer, television performer | known_for = | spouse = | website = }}
'''Maura Verónica Rivera Díaz''' (born December 18, 1984) is a popular [[Chile]]an [[<!-- what style? -->dancer]], television performer, and sex symbol.
Rivera was born in [[Santiago, Chile]]. She was a stable member of the Clan Rojo, on [[TVN (Chile)|TVN]]'s [[TV show]] ''Rojo Fama Contra Fama'' from its inception in 2002 to its restructuring in 2008. Among her achievements are a gold record,<ref>[http://archivo.eluniverso.com/2006/11/11/0001/259/213AC25DFE084F63B0E2329A3C5B29C2.aspx Maura Rivera en la presentación del disco de Andrea Bucaram - El Universo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606121640/http://archivo.eluniverso.com/2006/11/11/0001/259/213AC25DFE084F63B0E2329A3C5B29C2.aspx |date=2009-06-06 }} {{es}}</ref> winning the competition of the "Símbolo Rojo",<ref>[http://www.lacuarta.cl/diario/2003/10/26/26.21.4a.ESP.MAURA.html Maura Rivera ganó Símbolo Rojo - La Cuarta] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415215730/http://www.lacuarta.cl/diario/2003/10/26/26.21.4a.ESP.MAURA.html |date=2009-04-15 }}</ref> and the highest score of the program.
On September 8, 2008, she helped organize a march against the [[Chilean rodeo]],<ref>[http://latercera.cl/contenido/30_46989_9.shtml Maura Rivera lidera marcha contra maltrato animal en rodeos - La Tercera] {{es}}</ref><ref>[http://www.lacuarta.cl/contenido/65_19178_9.shtml Maura y lolos ecológicos pitearon con fuerza contra el rodeo - La Cuarta] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201075611/http://www.lacuarta.cl/contenido/65_19178_9.shtml |date=2008-12-01 }} {{es}}</ref> organized by <!-- group? organization? Are they popular? -->[[AnimaNaturalis]].<ref>[http://www.animanaturalis.org/post/20080907_Cientos_de_personas_dijeron_no_al_rodeo Cientos de personas dijeron no al rodeo - AnimaNaturalis] {{es}}</ref> In an interview Rivera expressed her passion for animals and how she detested the use of fur in fashion.<ref>[http://lacuarta.cl/contenido/63_19117_9.shtml Maura protesta contra el rodeo: "Ojalá la gente se pusiera en el lugar del novillo" - La Cuarta] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519194703/http://lacuarta.cl/contenido/63_19117_9.shtml |date=2009-05-19 }} {{es}}</ref> In early 2016, Rivera became a [[vegetarian]] for ethical reasons.<ref>{{cite web|last=Beltrán|first=Alejandro|accessdate=26 March 2018|url=https://www.pagina7.cl/notas/redes-sociales/2016/05/29/la-radical-decision-de-maura-rivera-que-saco-aplausos-de-sus-seguidores-en-instagram.shtml|website=[[Página7]]|title=La radical decisión de Maura Rivera que sacó aplausos de sus seguidores en Instagram|language=es|publicationdate=29 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160601075641/https://www.pagina7.cl/notas/redes-sociales/2016/05/29/la-radical-decision-de-maura-rivera-que-saco-aplausos-de-sus-seguidores-en-instagram.shtml|archivedate=1 June 2016}}</ref>
She supported Chilean <!-- right/left/centrist? -->presidential candidate [[Sebastián Piñera]]<!-- what year? -->.{{cn|date=March 2018}}
Rivera is the wife of [[CD Universidad Católica]] footballer [[Mark González]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.publimetro.cl/nota/espectaculos/mark-gonzalez-y-maura-rivera-se-casaron-por-el-civil-en-vina-del-mar/xIQjlw!T4GCDXr3tPdt | title = Publimetro - Mark González y Maura Rivera se casaron por el civil en Viña del Mar }}<!--Bot-generated title-->{{es}}</ref>
==''Rojo Fama Contrafama''== The last competition in which Maura Rivera participated, the "Rojo Fama Contrafama", she faced the winners of the first three competitions through testing totally new to the program. Of the 15 singers and 16 dancers participating only 8 of each would be selected for a year-long contract with TVN. Maura Rivera earned staunch public support during the show and took part in "Clan of Gold". Rivera was judged eighth in the competition by the actual jury.
While she was already known in by most in the country, it was not until a musical gala in the show ''Gran Rojo'' in the second season that Maura Rivera consolidated her position as one of the most popular personalities on "Rojo Fama Contra Fama". The dancer scored the highest of the night and the highest in the history of the popular program, at 44 points.
After becoming popular, Rivera was invited by the show to record a song with her partner [[Yamna Lobos]]. They recorded a [[cover version|cover]] of the song "La Cocotera" (The Coconut) and earned a gold record.
==After Rojo== Maura Rivera later competed in IWT's ''Stars on Ice''<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.terra.cl/entretencion/index.cfm?id_cat=2471&id_reg=1012772 | title = Terra - Destreza de Keitel y escote de Maura descoll - Entretenimiento }}<!--Bot-generated title-->{{es}}</ref> and was a panelist on Channel 13's ''Alfombra Roja''"<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.terra.cl/entretencion/index.cfm?id_cat=118&id_reg=1110583 | title = Terra - Maura opinóloga: "Hay mucha gente a la que t - Entretenimiento }}<!--Bot-generated title-->{{es}}</ref> and ''Viña 50 Años''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://enescena.canal13.cl/cgi-bin/link.exe/Television/367900?tpl=tv_i.tpl | title = Imprimir - Maura Rivera habla en exclusiva de su llegada a Canal 13 }}<!--Bot-generated title-->{{es}}</ref> The dancer also starred in the music video "Lady Love Me" by the group Canal Magdalena.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.terra.cl/musica/index.cfm?id_cat=115&id_reg=1028698 | title = Terra - Maura Rivera protagoniza nuevo videoclip de Canal Mag - Música }}<!--Bot-generated title-->{{es}}</ref>
==Measurements== *height: 1.65 m (5 ft 5 in)
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100330092124/http://especiales.tvn.cl/Rojo/maurarivera3/ Especial de Maura Rivera] at Televisión Nacional de Chile
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rivera, Maura}} [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:People from Santiago]] [[Category:Chilean female dancers]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Chilean expatriates in Russia]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Figure skating reality television participants]]

[[Chauncey Bailey]] was an American journalist who was murdered in [[Oakland, California]] in August 2007 to prevent him from publishing an investigative piece into the finances of [[Your Black Muslim Bakery]]. ==Murder== Bailey was shot and killed while working on a story about the finances of [[Your Black Muslim Bakery]], involving its pending bankruptcy.{{cite news | url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/13812780/detail.html | title=Police Link Bailey Homicide To Black Muslim Group | work=KTVU News | date=2007-08-03 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817105429/http://www.ktvu.com/news/13812780/detail.html | archivedate=2007-08-17 | df= }}{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/ci_6544355 | title=Cops: Editor's killer confesses |author1=Harry Harris |author2=Kristin Bender |author3=Kelly Rayburn |lastauthoramp=yes | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-04}} After the shooting, the ''Post'' publisher Paul Cobb revealed on television that, prior to Bailey's killing, Cobb had withheld from publication a story that Bailey had written earlier, saying only that it was about "things like" what happened to Bailey. He later stated that the police had asked him not to reveal anything about the matter. On August 6, 2007 a former employee of the bakery, Ali Saleem Bey, who is not a relative of the bakery's owner, but who adopted the Bey name, revealed that he was Bailey's source for the withheld story, which the ''Post'' had decided was not ready for publication. Bailey had asked Bey to give him the story.{{cite news | url=http://origin.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_6562958 | title=Slain editor's bakery source surfaces | author=Josh Richman | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-07}} According to Ali Bey, the bakery business had been seized from its rightful heirs in a coup through fraud and forgery, by a ruthless, younger branch of the family, beginning with Antar Bey and culminating with the current chief executive officer, [[Yusuf Bey IV]]. Ali revealed that in June 2005, John Bey, the former head of the Bey security service, was driven out of town with his family after an attempt on his life in a shooting outside his home. John had tried to expose the fraud behind the coup. In 2005, Antar Bey mortgaged the bakery property, to cover back taxes and other debt, and then defaulted, which led to threat of foreclosure. An attorney for the ''Post'' also confirmed that Bailey had been working on the story about the "financial status of the organization" and including the possibly criminal "activities of a number of people who were working in the organization". On October 24, 2006, Your Black Muslim Bakery, Inc. filed for [[Chapter 11]] bankruptcy, listing its CEO as Yusuf Ali Bey, otherwise known as Yusuf Bey IV. With $900,000 in debts, owed mostly to the mortgage holder, the building was about to be foreclosed upon. The remaining debt, $200,000, was owed to the [[Internal Revenue Service]]. The day after Bailey's death, on August 3, 2007 U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Edward Jellen ordered the case to be converted to [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7]] liquidation effective August 9, 2007.{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_6544356 | title=Esteemed enterprise spirals out of control |author1=Angela Hill |author2=Josh Richman |lastauthoramp=yes | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-04}} ==Final days== By 2007 Bailey was living in an apartment near the south end of [[Lake Merritt]], not far from downtown Oakland.{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_6534337 | title=Prominent journalist shot dead in street |author1=Harry Harris |author2=Angela Hill |lastauthoramp=yes | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-03}} He was known to walk to work as a daily routine, and to stop for breakfast at a [[McDonald's]] restaurant at 14th Street and Jackson Street, about a half-block from where he was killed in the 200 block of 14th Street, becoming Oakland's 72nd homicide of 2007. On the morning of August 2, 2007, Bailey set out on his usual walk to work. Unknown to him, Devaughndre Broussard, a 19-year-old handyman at Your Black Muslim Bakery, who was on probation for a San Francisco robbery conviction, had discovered Bailey's residence. Broussard had worked at the bakery as a handyman and cook between August 2006 and March 2007, before leaving to find other work. He was rehired at the bakery in July 2007. ===Assassination=== Broussard then, in a white [[Ford Aerostar]] van, began driving around the route he thought Bailey would be taking to work. Broussard insisted that he acted alone, but police believe he had an accomplice in the van. At 7:25 a.m. Broussard spotted Bailey leaving the McDonald's restaurant where Bailey regularly stopped to eat breakfast. Broussard then got out of the van, parked on Alice Street. Wearing a mask and dark clothing, he approached Bailey with the shotgun. A witness said Bailey said: "Please don't kill me." The witness claimed he recognized Bailey, and that he was in trouble, but stopped in his tracks when he saw the shotgun.{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/ci_6571657 | title=Cops: Killer 'stalked' editor prior to ambush |author1=Harry Harris |author2=Martin G. Reynolds |lastauthoramp=yes | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-08}} As he walked from home to work, Bailey was shot dead around 7:30 a.m. on 14th Street near Alice Street in Oakland's [[Lakeside Apartments District, Oakland, California|Lakeside Apartments District]] in what police described as an assassination. Witnesses said the single gunman wearing dark clothing and a ski mask approached Bailey and fired at least three rounds from a shotgun, hitting Bailey at least once in the chest, then fled on foot to a waiting van and drove off.{{cite news | url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/13805439/detail.html | title=Veteran Reporter Gunned Down In Oakland | work=KTVU News | date=2007-08-02}} The gunman first fired a shotgun blast at Bailey's chest, then stood over him and fired again [[execution style]] at Bailey's face while Bailey was down, and then fired a [[coup de grâce]] to make sure he was dead. The assassin then escaped in the van. Bailey was pronounced dead at the scene. Police Chief Wayne Tucker described the killing as "unusual" because it occurred downtown and in broad daylight.{{cite news | url=http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/08/02/BAGGCRBL8A6.DTL&tsp=1 | title=Hit man kills newspaper editor on Oakland street |author1=Christopher Heredia |author2=Leslie Fulbright |author3=Marisa Lagos |lastauthoramp=yes | work=San Francisco Chronicle | date=2007-08-02}} The [[Mossberg 500|Mossberg]] shotgun used in the murder was later identified as one stolen during a liquor store vandalism two years prior suspected to have been committed by members of [[Your Black Muslim Bakery]].{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/10/05/MNELSL1NT.DTL&tsp=1 | title=Trail of the shotgun in editor's slaying | author=Jaxon Van Derbeken | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | date=2007-10-05}} Bailey was survived by his father, three of his four siblings, and his teenage son living in southern California. A funeral mass was held at the East Oakland St. Benedict's Catholic Church on the morning of August 8, 2007, with an overflowing crowd of 700 in attendance, including a line of people outside for more than an hour into the service. Attendees included Oakland Mayor [[Ron Dellums]], [[U.S. Representative]] [[Barbara Lee]], actress Luenell, assistant dean of the [[University of California at Berkeley]] Graduate School of Journalism [[Paul Grabowicz]] who once worked with Bailey at the Tribune, and well-known local attorney [[John Burris]]. Bailey was buried at [[Holy Sepulchre Cemetery (Hayward, California)|Holy Sepulchre Cemetery]] in nearby [[Hayward, California|Hayward]].{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_6563000?source=most_emailed | title=Oakland newsman Bailey to be laid to rest Wednesday | author=Kristin Bender | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-07}}{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_6581036?source=most_viewed | title=Hundreds mourn Bailey |author1=Angela Hill |author2=Jamaal Johnson |author3=Cecily Burt |lastauthoramp=yes | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-09}} ==Suspects== === Shooter === Devaughndre Broussard grew up in San Francisco's [[Western Addition]] district. The office of the San Francisco District Attorney revealed that in January 2006, at age 18, Broussard plead guilty to an assault charge, and served a first-time offender sentence of one year in San Francisco county jail. Upon release, Broussard was also ordered to three years of supervised probation.{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_6571658?source=most_viewed | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929103238/http://www.insidebayarea.com/ci_6571658?source=most_viewed | title=Bakery leader, cohorts charged |author1=Harry Harris |author2=Paul T. Rosynsky | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-08 | archivedate=2007-09-29 | accessdate=2008-09-11}} In addition to his probation status, he was wanted on an outstanding failure-to-appear warrant for his arrest, charged with a 2006 assault with a firearm in San Francisco.{{cite news | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_6550155 | title=Confessed killer: I'm 'a good soldier' |author1=Angela Hill |author2=Harry Harris |lastauthoramp=yes | work=The Oakland Tribune | date=2007-08-05}} Police revealed that on the night of August 1, 2007, Broussard first went looking for Bailey at his apartment complex, having discovered Bailey's residence near the south end of Lake Merritt. Early on the next morning of August 2, 2007 Broussard looked for Bailey at his office, but Bailey had not yet arrived. Police revealed that Broussard also went looking for Bailey twice again at his apartment complex that morning. At 7:17 a.m. an [[AC Transit]] bus driver may have seen Broussard near Bailey's apartment, standing outside with the shotgun at First Avenue and International Boulevard. The driver called his dispatcher, who reported the incident to the Alameda County Sheriff's Office. The driver continued on his route, and deputies responded to the location, but could not locate the man in their search. ===Yusuf Bey IV=== {{Infobox criminal | name = Yusuf Bey IV | image_name = | image_alt = | image_caption = Yusuf Bey IV | birth_name = Yusuf Bey IV | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1986}} | birth_place = [[Oakland, California]] | death_date = | death_place = | alias = |charge = Murder | conviction_penalty = [[Life imprisonment]] | conviction_status = [[Incarceration|Incarcerated]] | occupation = Baker | allegiance = [[African-American Muslims|Black Muslims]] }} Yusuf Bey IV was born in Oakland in 1986, the son of Daulet and [[Yusuf Bey]], the latter of whom was the founder of the [[Your Black Muslim Bakery]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.chaunceybaileyproject.org/2009/08/02/yusuf-bey-iv-grew-up-in-prominent-yet-troubled-bakery/ |title=Yusuf Bey IV grew up in prominent yet troubled bakery |author1=Mary Fricker |author2=Bob Butler |author3=Thomas Peele |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=[[The Chauncey Bailey Project]] |date=August 2, 2009 }} His life was marred by arrests and accusations of serious crimes. {{cite news |url=http://www.eastbaytimes.com/oaklandtribune/ci_7223092?source=pkg |title=Bey IV's rap sheet spans wide range of criminal charges |author=Josh Richman |work=[[Oakland Tribune]] |date=2007-10-19 }} Bey IV lived a chaotic, violent life before his arrest for participating in the murder of journalist Chauncey Bailey. Yusuf Bey IV grew up in what must have been a turbulent home. His father Yusuf Bey had several children with multiple women, and in 1988, when Bey IV was two, three of the women left the home and took their nine children with them. At the time of his death in 2003, Bey Sr. was said to have fathered 42 children by various women. He had one legal wife, Farieda Bey. Bey's followers and "wives" often took his surname, although no legal adoptions or marriages took place. Bey claimed he had "spiritually" adopted followers who used his name. {{cite news |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/content/printVersion/210666/ |title=The Killing of a Journalist |author=Chris Thompson |work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=July 31, 2007 }} People who worked for the bakery were considered "members" of the business and the [[mosque]] from which the bakery had grown. {{cite news |url=http://www.eastbaytimes.com/ci_8689451 |title=Police reopen 68 case similar to Bailey slaying |author1=Bob Butler |author2=Thomas Peele |lastauthoramp=yes |work=Oakland Tribune |date=2008-03-25 }} Bey IV was arrested in [[El Cerrito, California]], in September 2001 after failing to stop at a stop sign. Police discovered a magazine with bullets in his possession. He was 15 at the time. Despite years of suspicion and serious brushes with the law, Yusuf Bey Sr. remained uncharged with any wrongdoing until 2002. {{cite news |url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/gyrobase/how-official-oakland-kept-the-bey-empire-going/Content?oid=1068787&showFullText=true |title=How Official Oakland Kept the Bey Empire Going: Blood & Money, Part Two: The Influence |author=Chris Thompson |work=[[East Bay Express]] |date=November 22, 2002 }} In that year, he was accused of [[lewd conduct]] by a girl who had been a [[foster child]] of Nora and Yusuf Bey twenty years earlier. [[DNA]] evidence was conclusive enough for prosecutors to schedule a court date, but before the trial could begin, Bey died of [[cancer]]. {{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/A-FATHER-S-FIEFDOM-REDUCED-TO-RUIN-2498377.php |title=A Father's Fiefdom Reduced To Ruin |author1=Erin McCormick |author2=Jaxon Van Derbeken |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=October 8, 2007 }} Bey Sr. had spent years preaching [[African American Muslims|Black Muslim]] sermons on Oakland radio, and the arrest and charge came as a somewhat of a shock to the surrounding community, who regarded the elder Bey as a local hero because of his renowned business, his support for [[Black Power|black empowerment]], his association with prominent politicians, and his supposed adherence to his Black Muslim faith. ===Battle for control of the bakery=== After the death of Bey Sr., Waajid Aljawwaad (who sometimes used the additional last name of Bey), a follower of Bey Sr., became the [[CEO]] of the business as Yusuf Bey Sr.'s designated successor. However, on February 27, 2004, Aljawwaad failed to arrive for work at the bakery. His body, bound with electrical tape and wrapped in a tarpaulin, was found in Oakland Hills in July of that year. No one was ever charged with the crime. [[Antar Bey]], Daulet and Yusuf Bey's son and older brother of Yusuf Bey IV, seized control of the bakery. Antar's half siblings and their mothers protested and fought with him over control of the business, but to no avail; Antar was able to retain control and force them out. He soon took out $700,000 in loans that went into default. {{cite web |url=https://bobbutler.wordpress.com/2011/03/23/chauncey-bailey-murder-trial-day-one/ |title=Chauncey Bailey Murder Trial, Day One |author=Bob Butler |publisher=[[WordPress]] |date=March 23, 2011 }} But in October 2005, Antar was killed in a [[carjacking]] in Oakland. Authorities suspected Yusuf Bey IV of ordering Antar's execution but could not provide proof. Oakland police charged a man unrelated to the bakery with the murder. After this, Bey IV took full control of the business. ====Bakery ownership years (2005–2007)==== Bey IV seemed primarily interested in the profits the bakery earned and the power over the members of the business his father had engendered, not the day-to-day operation of the business. He alternately took money from the business and conducted various fraud operations to support himself and the business before it failed. His father, the bakery and its members had enjoyed years of protection from the media and politicians against bad publicity, investigations and even prosecution, continuing up to the lewd conduct charge against Yusuf Bey Sr. After the death of his father, gaining control of the bakery and associated security businesses, and triumph over the feuding family members, Bey IV's crimes grew more and more serious. Despite several arrests, he remained free and flouted subpoenas and ignored court dates. His lawyer said at the time, "The view was, 'We're Black Muslims, we can do anything we want.' They got sucked in. I thought it was 'acting out' behavior. But it caused just a whirlwind of trouble." Bey IV continued his father's practice of delivering fiery Black Muslim sermons to bakery followers. In one videotaped sermon dated to July 2007, Bey IV said, "We fight the government, we fight the police, we fight our own families, we fight our own people, and we fight Caucasian people daily—just to do right." {{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Bey-IV-speeches-a-month-before-Bailey-killed-3230888.php |title=Bey IV speeches a month before Bailey killed |author=Jaxon Van Derbeken |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=January 29, 2008 }} Some of the crimes Bey IV committed during this period included theft by deception and forgery involving the purchase of several cars; fraudulent [[sub-prime]] home loan applications; possession of a firearm after attempting to open a checking account using forged identification; and a bizarre kidnapping and assault on a woman Bey IV believed was connected with drug dealers who owed him money, or whom he could rob. ====Criminal record==== Below are some of the charges and arrests for Yusuf Bey IV. * In November 2005, Bey IV was charged with grand theft for fraud connected with the purchase of a 2002 [[Mercedes (car)|Mercedes]] from a [[Vallejo, California|Vallejo]] car dealership. He used a stolen identity to buy the car and pleaded no contest when the crime was discovered. A [[Solano County, California|Solano County]] judge allowed him to remain free. * That same month, a group of men in suits, presumably led by Bey IV, stormed two Muslim-owned stores that sold liquor. The men destroyed wine in cases and groceries. Bey IV later claimed, "If you say you're a Muslim, you should have the action of a Muslim," and that alcohol was "killing our people". * In 2006, Bey IV was charged with [[assault with a deadly weapon]] after he tried to run over the [[Bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]] of a San Francisco strip club from which he'd been ejected. * In June 2006, Bey IV purchased a home in Oakland using falsified information. The sub-prime loan involved a first and second mortgage, and investigators later theorized the motive was to obtain money from the home's equity. The loan went into [[default (finance)|default]] in October. Bey IV used his own [[Social Security number]] but a [[driver's license]] with a falsified name for the loan paperwork. Later, investigators discovered that Bey IV and his associates had purchased a total of five homes, most of which were in default. * That same month, Bey IV and some associates used false information to buy three cars from a [[San Bruno]] dealership, which later resulted in charges of grand theft. Bey IV used the same name to purchase the cars that he had used to purchase the house in Oakland. One of the accomplices later said he could not remember using a false name or several other details of the fraudulent car purchase or the liquor store vandalism, in which he also allegedly participated. {{cite web |url=http://www.chaunceybaileyproject.org/2011/04/28/reluctant-witnesses-take-the-stand-in-chauncey-bailey-trial/ |title=Reluctant witnesses take the stand in Chauncey Bailey trial |author=Thomas Peele |publisher=The Chauncey Bailey Project |date=April 28, 2011 }} * In May 2007, Bey IV and four men kidnapped a woman and took her to the home of Bey's brother-in-law. The men beat the blindfolded woman and demanded money supposedly owed to Bey IV. While the crime was in progress, police saw a [[Crown Victoria]], a car often used by police, outside the house and grew suspicious. Police went to the door and the men fled on foot, leaving their cars behind. The police confiscated the vehicles as evidence and Joshua Bey, Bey IV's half-brother, was arrested. Since the arrest, Bey IV has alternately admitted and denied various aspects of this crime. {{cite web |url=http://www.chaunceybaileyproject.org/2008/10/25/bey-iv-run-ins-with-the-law/ |title=Bey IV run-ins with the law |author=Unsigned |publisher=The Chauncey Bailey Project |date=October 25, 2008 }} * Bey IV wanted Alfonza Phillips Sr., the father of the man who killed Antar Bey, executed. But because Bey IV's [[accomplice]] Devaughndre Broussard could not find Phillips, Bey IV told him to kill another relative of the carjacker, Odell Roberson.{{cite news |url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/chauncey-bailey/ci_17827815 |title=Your Black Muslim Bakery leader had Chauncey Bailey killed, bakery follower testifies |author=Thomas Peele |work=Oakland Tribune |date=April 12, 2011 }} In July 2007, Broussard, who was 19, found Roberson. Antoine Mackey, another member of the bakery, handed him a rifle, and Broussard shot the unarmed man. He said at trial that he had fired eight or ten rounds and carried out the murder "because Yusuf Bey IV told me to". {{cite web |url=http://www.chaunceybaileyproject.org/2011/03/28/broussard-bursts-into-laughter-describing-2007-slaying/ |title=Broussard bursts into laughter describing 2007 slaying |author=Thomas Peele |publisher=The Chauncey Bailey Project |date=March 28, 2011 }} * Later in 2007, Bey IV, Antoine Mackey and Devaughndre Broussard were driving around Oakland discussing the [[Zebra murders|"Zebra" murders]]. Bey IV or Broussard saw Michael Wills, a white man who worked as a chef, returning to work on foot after purchasing a pack of cigarettes. Bey IV and his accomplices discussed who should kill Wills and Mackey volunteered. He got out of the car and shot Wills six times. The three left the scene and returned to the bakery compound. ==Investigation and trial for murder== On the day of the killing Oakland Police and [[Crime Stoppers]] of Oakland offered up to $25,000 in reward money for information leading to the arrest of the killer. Beginning early at 5 a.m. on the following morning of August 3, 2007, more than 200 Oakland police officers and [[SWAT]] team members armed with [[search warrant]]s closed off a number of blocks of [[San Pablo Avenue]], a major thoroughfare in North Oakland. The area of focus included homes and the business properties of [[Your Black Muslim Bakery]], which operated two business locations on either side of the street between Stanford Avenue and 59th Street. The group is a [[African American Muslims|Black Muslim]] splinter organization founded by [[Yusuf Bey]], and now led by his son [[Yusuf Bey IV]]. The pre-dawn raids followed a two-month investigation into a variety of violent crimes, including kidnapping and murder. Police used stun grenades and broke down doors to gain entry. In a news conference later that day, Oakland Deputy Police Chief Howard Jordan said that several weapons and other evidence of value linked the killing of Chauncey Bailey to members of the group. Police also recovered spent ammunition from the rooftops, and detained 19 people for questioning. In addition to the bakeries, the police also raided nearby homes. In the 1000 block of 59th Street, police recovered, from a closet, the shotgun used in the killing of Bailey at the home where Broussard was also detained. The rear yard of the home connected directly to the bakery property. Police also raided a home in the 900 block of Aileen Street a few blocks east of the bakery. Of the 19 detainees on that morning, five were arrested along with Broussard, and Yusuf Bey IV, on probable cause arrest warrants, along with other outstanding arrest warrants, stemming from the prior investigations. Broussard was booked on suspicion of murder on August 4, 2007, for the killing of Bailey, having told police detectives that he considered himself "a good soldier". Though other charges were made against those arrested, none of them were charged with Bailey's murder. On August 7 Broussard was arraigned in Alameda County Superior Court, on charges of murder and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon. Broussard initially confessed to killing Bailey, then recanted his confession. In a 2008 ''[[60 Minutes]]'' interview, Broussard claimed he was coerced by Yusuf Bey IV to plead guilty for the benefit of the bakery and others arrested.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/10/60minutes/main20040084.shtml |title=Transcript: Devaughndre Broussard Interview (Anderson Cooper) |author1=Cooper, Anderson |author2=Broussard, Devaughndre |lastauthoramp=yes |date=March 10, 2011 |work=60 Minutes |publisher=CBSNews |accessdate=2011-03-28}} In an interview for CBS News, Broussard said that the Oakland Police put him and Bey IV together in a room, and that Bey IV convinced him to plead guilty for the purpose of releasing other murder suspects.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/03/10/60minutes/main20040084.shtml | work=CBS News | title=Transcript: Devaughndre Broussard Interview}} He later pled guilty to manslaughter charges in exchange for a 25-year sentence and full testimony at the trial of Bey IV and others.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/03/28/BAF01IKVNI.DTL&tsp=1 |title=Chauncey Bailey shooter laughed at killings |author=Lee, Henry K. |date=March 28, 2011 |work= |publisher=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=2011-03-28}} In June 2008 a videotape of Bey IV in custody whispering to his half-brother Joshua Bey and another bakery associate, Tamon Halfin, and disclosing details of Bailey's murder was obtained and posted by the Chauncey Bailey Project. {{cite news |url=http://www.eastbaytimes.com/ci_9630229 |title=Secret video raises questions about bakery leader's role in Bailey killing |author=Thomas Peele, Bob Butler, Mary Fricker and Josh Richman |work=[[East Bay Times]] |date= June 18, 2008 }} Journalists from the Chauncey Bailey Project created a transcription of the conversation which seemed to indicate Bey was involved in Bailey's murder. A grand jury indicted Bey IV with ordering the execution of Chauncey Bailey in April 2009, almost two years after the murder. {{cite web |url=http://www.religionnewsblog.com/23433/your-black-muslim-bakery-11 |title=Leader of Your Black Muslim Bakery indicted in journalist’s slaying |publisher=Religion News Blog |date=April 30, 2009 }} Broussard testified for the prosecution at the trial of Bey IV and Antoine Mackey in 2011. He stated in court that Bey ordered him to find, track and kill Bailey before the journalist could print his latest article on the bakery. On June 9, 2011 Bey IV and Mackey were both convicted by a trial jury of multiple counts of murder{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/06/09/BADE1JRSPI.DTL |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612132400/http://www.sfgate.com:80/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/06/09/BADE1JRSPI.DTL||archive-date=June 12, 2011 |dead-url=yes|title=Your Black Muslim Bakery leader guilty of murder |author=Lee, Henry K. |date=June 9, 2011 |work= |publisher=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=2011-06-10}} and sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.{{cite news|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8328565|title=Two men sentenced to life in prison in Chauncey Bailey murder case|last=Anthony|first=Laura|date=August 26, 2011|work=KGO-TV|accessdate=4 August 2013}} Yusuf Bey IV was found guilty of three counts of first-degree murder.{{cite web |author=Thomas Peele |url=http://www.chaunceybaileyproject.org/2011/06/09/former-your-black-muslim-bakery-leader-yusuf-bey-iv-guilty-for-murdering-chauncey-bailey/|title=Former Your Black Muslim Bakery leader Yusuf Bey IV guilty for murdering Chauncey Bailey|accessdate=9 June 2011}} In 2013 Bey's attorney, Lorna Brown, was convicted of smuggling documents out of jail for him. One of the documents, a hit list ordering an associate to kill a witness, was intercepted by police before the associate could carry out the murder.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_23665422/judge-calls-four-year-suspension-lawyer-who-admitted|title=Judge calls for four-year suspension for lawyer who admitted smuggling documents for Yusuf Bey IV|last=Peele|first=Thomas|date=July 15, 2013|work=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=4 August 2013}} In 2015, a state appeals court upheld the convictions of Yusuf Bey IV and Antoine Mackey.http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/2-lose-appeal-in-killing-of-Oakland-journalist-6018383.php Bey IV also threatened former bakery followers to intimidate them from testifying against him. Based on recorded calls between Bey IV and follower Kahlil Raheem, Bey first cajoled and then warned Raheem not to testify against him. {{cite web |url=http://www.chaunceybaileyproject.org/2009/08/25/bey-iv-tried-to-strong-arm-follower-recordings-reveal/ |title=Bey IV tried to strong-arm follower, recordings reveal |author=Thomas Peele |publisher=The Chauncey Bailey Project |date= August 25, 2009 }} As the trial progressed, allegations of intimidation by Bey IV and other former bakery members persisted. The ''Contra Costa Times'' editorialized on April 30, 2011, that the intimidation must stop and that the judge, [[Thomas Reardon]], along with bailiffs and the sheriff should get control of the trial to allow justice to be done. {{cite news |url=http://www.eastbaytimes.com/opinion/ci_17959440 |title=Contra Costa Times editorial: Judge, sheriff and bailiffs must stop witness intimidation in Bey trial |author=Editorial Board |work=Contra Costa Times |date= April 30, 2011 }} Some witnesses called to testify changed their story from the original information they gave the police or said they did not remember what happened. A man who worked at the convenience store that Bey IV allegedly attacked with his followers said he did not remember over 50 times at trial. {{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_17775759?nclick_check=1 |title=Bailey witness can't remember specific 'kill' order from Yusuf Bey IV |author=Thomas Peele |work=San Jose Mercury News |date=April 5, 2011 }} Even Broussard testified later that he does not remember Bey IV giving him specific orders to kill Odell Roberson or Chauncey Bailey. {{cite news |url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/top-stories/ci_17976421 |title=Another Bailey slaying trial witness has memory problems |author=Thomas Peele |work=Oakland Tribune |date= May 2, 2011 }} == See also == * [[Chauncey Bailey]] {{Portal bar|Biography|California|Law}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.chaunceybaileyproject.org/ Website dedicated to the memory of Chauncey Bailey, and his life and death] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bailey, Chauncey}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:People from Oakland, California]] [[Category:American chief executives of food industry companies]] [[Category:American businesspeople in retailing]] [[Category:Criminals of the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:American people convicted of theft]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by California]] [[Category:2007 murders in the United States]] [[Category:21st-century American criminals]] [[Category:Criminals from California]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:American businesspeople convicted of crimes]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Nelson Hackett|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Nelson Hackett''' (born c. 1810) was an escaped [[slavery|slave]] who fled to Canada. In 1841 he escaped from his [[Arkansas]] master, [[Alfred Wallace]] on a stolen horse, and 6 weeks later crossed the border and entered Canada.
Wallace, however, refused to let the matter drop, and he was well connected, particularly to the [[Governor of Arkansas]], [[Archibald Yell]]. Wallace and an associate, George C. Grigg, travelled to Canada and made out dispositions against Hackett for stealing the horse, as well as a gold watch belonging to Wallace.
Despite opposition from [[Upper Canada]]'s [[attorney general]], [[William Henry Draper]], Hackett was extradited to the United States on the order of [[Charles Bagot|Sir Charles Bagot]], due to his theft of the watch, which exceeded what was necessary to take in order to facilitate his escape to freedom. Public reaction from [[abolitionism|abolitionists]], in England, Canada and the United States was strong. Politicians in the [[British House of Commons]] and Upper Canada's executive council questioned the motives for the extradition, as well as its legality.
Wallace seems to have been intent on "teaching a lesson" to American slaves; namely that Canada would not prove to be a safe haven for them. The fact that his legal bills far exceeded Hackett's market value seems to bear this out. In any event, his strategy failed. Hackett's escape brought more attention to Canada as a refuge for slaves, and when the extradition clause of the [[Webster-Ashburton Treaty]] was finally negotiated, slaves were protected from extradition to their former American masters.
==External links== *[http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=3419 Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online'']
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hackett, Nelson}} [[Category:1810 births]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:American slaves]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:People extradited from Canada to the United States]]

revision.text:
'''Omar Oussedik''' ([[Transliteration|transliterate]]d variously) (1920 or 1922 in [[Ain El Hammam]], [[Algeria]] – June 1992 in [[Algiers]], [[Algeria]]) was an [[Algeria]]n [[nationalist]] politician and independence leader, born in a [[berber people|Berber]] family from the [[Kabylie]] region.[http://www.khouasweb.123.fr/articles.php?lng=fr&pg=1076]
At about age 22, he was drawn to the movement for Algerian self-rule and [[independence]], joining the [[Parti du peuple algérien]] (PPA) headed by [[Messali Hadj]]. Following the [[Sétif massacre]], he was among those who pushed for the formation of an armed clandestine network, the [[Organisation Spéciale]] (OS). The OS was soon crushed by France, and in 1948 he was arrested by [[France]] and imprisoned in [[Blida]] military prison, where he was tortured. After being freed in 1951, he left to live in France, where he was active in the Algerian [[labor movement]].
He returned to join the newly formed [[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|Front de libération nationale]] (FLN) in 1955, under the [[nom de guerre]] of '''Si Tayeb'''. During the Algerian [[Algerian War of Independence|War of Independence]] (1954–62), he held political missions such as a post in the provisional [[exile government]] of the FLN, the [[Gouvernement Provisoire de la République Algérienne]], (GPRA) between 1958 and 1960. He later worked as FLN representative in [[Guinea]], which supported the Algerian revolt.
After independence in 1962, he served as [[ambassador]] of Algeria in the [[Soviet Union]], [[Bulgaria]], [[India]] and [[Italy]], under then-[[foreign minister]] [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]]. He died in 1992.
==External links== * [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE2DC103FF936A25755C0A964958260 Obituary: June 15, 1992], ''[[New York Times]]''.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Oussedik, Omar}} [[Category:Algerian nationalists]] [[Category:Algerian Berber politicians]] [[Category:Algerian rebels]] [[Category:Kabyle people]] [[Category:Algerian People's Party politicians]] [[Category:National Liberation Front (Algeria) politicians]] [[Category:Algerian exiles]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Algeria to India]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Algeria to the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Algeria to Bulgaria]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Algeria to Italy]] [[Category:1920s births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:People from Ain El Hammam]]
{{Algeria-politician-stub}}

{{Use Indian English|date=May 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = P. I. Belliappa | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Pandyanda I Belliappa | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Kodagu]] ([[Coorg State|Coorg]]),
[[India]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Indian | other_names = | occupation = Freedom Fighter, Politician | known_for = }} '''Pandyanda I. Belliappa''' (or '''Pandianda I. Belliappa''') was a Gandhian, a freedom fighter and politician from the erstwhile state of [[Coorg]]. ==Freedom Struggle== Belliappa entered politics in 1921 as a member of the Coorg Planters' Association.{{cite book|title=Report on the Administration of Coorg|date=1923|publisher=Government of India|location=Coorg, India|page=19|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FZs-AQAAMAAJ&q=pandianda&dq=pandianda&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gqIhVOyEGpehugTbjoDYBw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBQ|accessdate=23 September 2014}} He later joined the Congress Party and became one of its prominent members.{{cite book|last1=Muthanna|first1=I. M.|title=A Tiny Model State of South India|date=1953|publisher=Tiny Spot|pages=103, 104|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ux9AAAAAMAAJ&q=P+I+Belliappa&dq=P+I+Belliappa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HqIhVOriIs_iuQT4n4KABg&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAw|accessdate=23 September 2014}} A staunch Gandhian, satyagrahi and freedom fighter he courted arrest during the freedom struggle. His wife Pandyanda Seethamma Belliappa was also a freedom fighter who courted arrest.{{cite book|last1=Kumar|first1=Radha|title=The History of Doing: An Illustrated Account of Movements for Women's Rights .|page=80|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68xTBT1-H4IC&pg=PA80&dq=pandyanda&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Z6IhVIrDFZLIuASHyYCYCg&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=pandyanda&f=false|accessdate=23 September 2014}} He was also the editor of a periodical called the 'Kodagu'. At his invitation, [[Mahatma Gandhi]], his secretary Mr. Thakkar, the President of the Dalit Sangha, a German journalist, Miss Jamnalal Bajaj and others came to Gonikoppal in Coorg.{{cite book|title=Gandhi's campaign against untouchability, 1933-34: an account from the Raj's secret official reports|date=1996|publisher=[[Gandhi Peace Foundation]]|page=111|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZxRuAAAAMAAJ&q=P+I+Belliappa&dq=P+I+Belliappa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HqIhVOriIs_iuQT4n4KABg&ved=0CCwQ6AEwBA|accessdate=23 September 2014}} ==Coorg State== In 1952, he separated from the Congress along with others and fought the Coorg state elections as independents while floating a new party called the Takkadi ('justice scales') party. The issue they fought against was the proposed merger of Coorg with Mysore. They lost the elections to the Congress, led by C M Poonacha, but won nine of the Assembly seats. The Takkadi party was a dominant political force and voice in Coorg with its anti-merger plank.{{cite news|last1=RAMACHANDRA|first1=C.M.|title=Coorg and the reorganisation of States|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/coorg-and-the-reorganisation-of-states/article5253017.ece|accessdate=23 September 2014|agency=The Hindu|publisher=The Hindu|date=20 October 2013}}{{cite news|last1=CHINNAPPA|first1=K. JEEVAN|title=Kodagu fighting to maintain its existence|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/kodagu-fighting-to-maintain-its-existence/article5930024.ece|accessdate=23 September 2014|agency=The Hindu|publisher=The Hindu|date=20 April 2014}}{{cite book|last1=Muthanna|first1=I. M.|title=A Tiny Model State of South India|date=1953|publisher=Tiny Spot,|location=Coorg|page=119|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ux9AAAAAMAAJ&q=P+I+Belliappa&dq=P+I+Belliappa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HqIhVOriIs_iuQT4n4KABg&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAw|accessdate=23 September 2014}}{{cite book|last1=Park|first1=Richard Leonard|title=Reports on the Indian general elections, 1951-52|date=1956|publisher=Popular Book Depot,|page=272|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=klA5AQAAIAAJ&q=P+I+Belliappa&dq=P+I+Belliappa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HqIhVOriIs_iuQT4n4KABg&ved=0CEIQ6AEwCA|accessdate=23 September 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Belliappa, P. I.}} [[Category:Indian independence activists from Karnataka]] [[Category:Kodava people]] [[Category:People from Kodagu district]] [[Category:Gandhians]] [[Category:Indian National Congress politicians from Karnataka]] [[Category:Coorg State politicians]] [[Category:Coorg State MLAs 1952–56]] {{INC-politician-stub}} {{Karnataka-politician-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
'''Panos Kolokotronis''' ({{lang-el|Πάνος Κολοκοτρώνης}}) was the eldest son of the Greek General [[Theodoros Kolokotronis]] and his mother was Aikaterini Karousou ({{lang-el|Αικατερίνη Καρούσου}}). He was born on the island of [[Zakynthos]] in 1800, while his father was serving there as a Major in the British Infantry. He fought along with his father in the [[Greek War of Independence]] and distinguished himself in many battles.
In 1822, he married Eleni, the daughter of [[Laskarina Bouboulina]].
In 1825, during the second [[Greek civil wars of 1824–1825|civil war]], he was murdered in [[Tripoli]] by order of the revolutionary government.
== See also == * [[Theodoros Kolokotronis]] * [[Gennaios Kolokotronis]]

{{pp-pc1}} {{For|other people with similar names|Peter Davidson (disambiguation){{!}}Peter Davidson}} {{For|the song|Pete Davidson (song)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Pete Davidson | image =Pete Davidson in 2013.jpg | alt = Davidson looking away from the camera | caption = Davidson in 2013 | birth_name = Peter Michael Davidson<ref name="3opdj" /> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1993|11|16|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Staten Island|Staten Island, New York]], U.S. | active = 2010–present | partner = | medium = {{hlist|Stand-up|television|film}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Observational comedy]]|[[black comedy]]|[[insult comedy]]|[[deadpan]]|[[Surreal humour|surreal humor]]|[[satire]]}} | subject = {{hlist|[[Culture of the United States|American culture]]|[[Politics of the United States|American politics]]|[[everyday life]]|[[Sex differences in humans|gender differences]]|[[human behavior]]|[[Embarrassment|social awkwardness]]|[[dating]]|[[World news|current events]]|[[pop culture]]}} }}
'''Peter Michael Davidson''' (born November 16, 1993)<ref name="tvg" /> is an American comedian and actor. He is a cast member on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. Davidson has also appeared on the [[MTV]] shows ''[[Guy Code]]'', ''[[Wild 'n Out]]'', and ''[[Failosophy]]''.<ref name="MTV" /><ref name="5N6VJ" /> He has performed stand-up comedy on ''[[Adam DeVine's House Party]]'', ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', and ''[[Comedy Underground with Dave Attell]]'', and guest-starred in ''[[Brooklyn Nine-Nine]]''.<ref name="EW9.15.14" />
==Early life== Davidson was born November 16, 1993, in [[Staten Island|Staten Island, New York]], the son of Amy (''née'' Waters) and Scott Matthew Davidson.<ref name="tvg" /><ref name="sidad" /> His father was of mostly Jewish heritage and his mother is of Irish ancestry; Davidson was raised Catholic.<ref name="NYTimes" /><ref name="FmZVw" /> He has a younger sister named Casey.<ref name="fMHy6" /> His father was a [[New York City Fire Department|New York City firefighter]] who [[Emergency workers killed in the September 11 attacks|died in service]] during the [[September 11 attacks]];<ref name="nyp" /><ref name="ggwHy" /> he was last seen running up the stairs of the [[Marriott World Trade Center]], just prior to its collapse. Davidson, who was seven years old at the time, was profoundly affected by the loss. He told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that it was "overwhelming" and that he would often act out in school as a result of the trauma, at one point ripping his hair out until he was bald.<ref name="NYTimes" /> In October 2016, Davidson revealed on ''[[The Breakfast Club (radio show)|The Breakfast Club]]'' morning radio show that he struggled with suicidal thoughts when he was younger, and that the music of rap artist [[Kid Cudi]] saved his life.<ref name="Yahoo" />
Davidson first tried his hand at stand-up comedy at age 16 in a Staten Island bowling alley, where a group of friends, knowing of his comedy aspirations, dared him to take to the stage. He did so only after smoking marijuana.<ref name="SFChronicle" /> Davidson, who has suffered from [[Crohn's disease]] since the age of 17 or 18, at the time said he "cannot function" without marijuana, adding that he would not be able to work on ''Saturday Night Live'', and that attempts to perform without it have not been successful. He explained that he "can perform when [he's] not high, but it wouldn't be that much fun for [him]."<ref name="HighTimes" /> He attended [[St. Joseph by the Sea High School|St. Joseph by-the-Sea High School]], then [[Tottenville High School]] before transferring to [[Xaverian High School]] in Brooklyn where he graduated in 2011. His mother still works as the school nurse at the latter. Following high school, he enrolled at [[St. Francis College]] in [[Brooklyn Heights]],<ref name="sidad" /> remaining briefly before dropping out.<ref name="EW9.15.14" /><ref name="Diamondback" />
==Career== Davidson's earliest onscreen appearance was in the third episode of the MTV comedy series ''Failosophy'', which premiered February 28, 2013. The following month, he appeared in "PDA and Moms," a third-season episode of the [[MTV2]] reality TV comedy series ''[[Guy Code]]'', the first of four episodes in which he was featured.<ref name="MTV" /> That June, his first televised standup aired as part of a second-season episode of the [[Comedy Central]] program ''Gotham Comedy Live'', which showcases standup comedians at the Gotham Comedy Club in New York City. The following month, he returned to MTV2 with an appearance on ''[[Nick Cannon Presents: Wild 'N Out]]'', his first of six episode appearances on that show.
Davidson subsequently made standup appearances on ''[[Adam Devine's House Party]]'', ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', ''[[Comedy Underground with Dave Attell]]'', and guest-starred in ''[[Brooklyn Nine-Nine]]''. In 2014, he acquired a role in a Fox comedy pilot, ''Sober Companion'',<ref name="w7Qmd" /> but it ultimately did not make it to series.<ref name="2BTEh" />
Davidson joined the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' with that show's 40th-season premiere, which debuted on September 27, 2014. At age 20, he was the first ''SNL'' cast member to be born in the 1990s, and one of the youngest cast members ever.<ref name="Diamondback" /><ref name="62uvd" /> The first new addition to the cast that season,<ref name="EW9.15.14" /> Davidson was given a chance to audition for the show through regular [[Bill Hader]], whom he had met while filming a small part in the 2015 [[Judd Apatow]] feature film comedy ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]''.<ref name="EW9.29.14" /> Hader subsequently told producer [[Lorne Michaels]] about him. His debut garnered positive critical notice,<ref name="EW9.29.14" /><ref name="79ryC" /> with his most noted skits during the season including an ''[[Indiana Jones]]''-style sketch in which he and [[Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson]], after being pelted with poison darts, were forced to mutually suck poison out of each other's various body parts,<ref name="SFChronicle" /><ref name="wB33v" /> an endeavor that eventually found them entangled in the [[69 (sex position)|"69" position]].<ref name="kDWXs" /> Another involved Davidson being shot in the chest with an arrow by [[Norman Reedus]].<ref name="SFChronicle" />
In March 2015, Davidson was a roaster on the ''[[Comedy Central Roast]]'' of [[Justin Bieber]],<ref name="LvdAO" /> and his set was praised as one of the best of the show.<ref name="6kjF7" /> Among his bolder jokes was one at the expense of fellow roaster [[Snoop Dogg]] and host [[Kevin Hart]], and their 2004 film ''[[Soul Plane]]''. Davidson, whose firefighter father died responding to the September 11 attacks, called that film "the worst experience of my life involving a plane."<ref name="SFChronicle" />
In 2016, Davidson was on the [[Forbes 30 Under 30|''Forbes'' 30 under 30]] list.<ref name="forbes" /> Also in 2016, Davidson recorded his first stand-up special ''Pete Davidson: SMD.'' The [[Comedy Central]] special was filmed in [[New York City]]. He made an appearance on ''[[The Jim Gaffigan Show]].''{{cn|date=August 2018}}
In November 2018, Davidson was criticized for his comments mocking the Republican congressional candidate and veteran [[Dan Crenshaw]], who wears an eye patch because of an injury from the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]]. Davidson compared Crenshaw to a "hitman in a porno movie", and added, "I'm sorry, I know he lost his eye in war, or whatever."<ref name="aGWVs" /><ref name="sovs5" /><ref name="1f3JM" /><ref name="4sJV8" /> Davidson later invited Crenshaw for a Weekend Update segment on SNL. In the episode, Davidson apologized to Crenshaw, and they made further jokes and references that it is [[Veterans Day]].<ref name="Itzkoff" /> Crenshaw and others have speculated that the joke may have helped him win [[Texas's 2nd congressional district]] in the midterm election.<ref name="wapoJoke" /><ref name="esquire" />
==Comedy style== Davidson has been lauded for basing his comedy on his own life and employing aspects of his life that have been likened to "a series of brutal truths and vulgar confessions," and which make him relatable to audiences. Touching upon topics such as marijuana, sex, and relationships, incidents he relates include those from his awkward high school experiences to living in a dormitory during his brief stint at [[St. Francis College]].<ref name="Diamondback" /> Davidson jokes about highly sensitive subjects, including the loss of his father during the September 11 attacks, because, he says, he finds that it empowers him to address the feeling of powerlessness that experiencing such tragedy at a young age inflicted upon him.<ref name="NYTimes" /> He is a fan of the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' franchise, and has incorporated that material into his comedy work as well.<ref name="Diamondback" /><ref name="EW9.29.14" />
==Personal life== As of October 2015, Davidson lives in [[Brooklyn Heights|Brooklyn Heights, New York]].<ref name="NYTimes" />
The death of Davidson's father caused psychological problems for him growing up. His father was a [[Rescue and recovery effort after the September 11 attacks on the World Trade Center#Firefighters|firefighter and first-responder]] during the [[September 11 attacks]].<ref name="qWczX" /> Davidson has his father's badge number, 8418, tattooed on his left arm.<ref name="NYTimes" />
Davidson supported [[Hillary Clinton]] in the [[2016 U.S. presidential election]], and on December 5, 2017, he stated on his [[Instagram]] account that he got a tattoo on his leg of Clinton, whom he called his "hero", a "badass", and "one of the strongest people in the universe." Clinton herself thanked Davidson for the compliment, commenting, "This makes it significantly less awkward that I've had a Pete Davidson tattoo for years."<ref name="G5xOk" />
He was diagnosed with [[Crohn's disease]] at age 17 or 18,<ref name="HighTimes" /> for which he receives intravenous treatment<ref name="NYTimes" /> and used [[medical marijuana]] as a pain reliever.<ref name="HighTimes" /> On March 6, 2017, Davidson announced on his Instagram account that he had quit drugs and was sober for the first time in eight years.<ref name="Yahoo" /> During an interview on comedian [[Marc Maron]]'s podcast, Davidson clarified that the only drug he used was marijuana and, while he has since cut back its use considerably, the personal problems he initially assumed were a result of his daily marijuana habit were actually caused by [[borderline personality disorder]], for which he has since been undergoing treatment.<ref name="IxgX9" /><ref name="MtaTl" />
Davidson previously dated Cazzie David for two years.<ref name="Lrs1D" /><ref name="V9XXK" /><ref name="EWS63" /> On June 20, 2018, Davidson confirmed that he and singer and actress [[Ariana Grande]] were engaged to be married.<ref name="USAT Engagement" /> On October 14, 2018, it was reported that the engagement was called off.<ref name="mJ420" /><ref name="4G7kL" /><ref name="QewPQ" /> Grande's song "[[Pete Davidson (song)|Pete Davidson]]" appears on her 2018 album ''[[Sweetener (album)|Sweetener]]''.

{{other people|Richard Austin}} {{Infobox Congressman | name = Richard Wilson Austin | image = Richard-wilson-austin.jpg | width = 170px | state = [[Tennessee]] | district = [[Tennessee's 2nd congressional district|2nd]] | term_start = March 4, 1909 | term_end = March 3, 1919 | preceded = [[Nathan W. Hale]] | succeeded = [[J. Will Taylor]] | birth_date = {{birth-date|August 26, 1857}} | death_date = {{death-date and age|April 20, 1919|August 26, 1857}} | birth_place = [[Decatur, Alabama]] | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]] | resting_place = [[Old Gray Cemetery]]
[[Knoxville, Tennessee]]{{findagrave|8039096}} | citizenship = {{US}} | spouse = Margaret Morrison (m. 1882) | profession = [[Lawyer|Attorney]], editor, diplomat | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | alma_mater = [[University of Tennessee]] | residence = |nickname = |allegiance = |branch = |service_years = |rank = |unit = |commands = |battles = |awards = |}} '''Richard Wilson Austin''' (August 26, 1857 – April 20, 1919) was an [[United States|American]] politician, attorney and diplomat. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], he served in the [[United States House of Representatives]] from 1909 to 1919, representing [[Tennessee's 2nd congressional district|Tennessee's 2nd district]]. Prior to his congressional tenure, he worked as a [[United States Marshals Service|United States Marshal]] from 1897 to 1906, and served as the U.S. [[consul (representative)|consul]] to [[Glasgow, Scotland]], from 1906 to 1907."Richard Wilson Austin," ''[http://cmdc.knoxlib.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15136coll4/id/2536/rec/1 Men of Affairs in Knoxville]'' (Knoxville Lithographing Company, 1917). Accessed at the McClung Digital Collection, 16 August 2013. ==Early life== Austin was born on August 26, 1857, in [[Decatur, Alabama]], the son of John and Mary (Parker) Austin. He attended public schools in [[Loudon County, Tennessee]], and studied law at the [[University of Tennessee]]. He was admitted to the [[bar association|bar]] in 1878, and commenced practice in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]]. Austin served as a clerk in the [[Post Office Department]] at [[Washington, D.C.]], from 1879 to 1881. He worked as Assistant [[Doorkeeper of the United States House of Representatives]] under his future political ally, [[Walter P. Brownlow]], from 1881 to 1883, during the [[Forty-seventh United States Congress|Forty-seventh Congress]]. He was a special agent of the [[United States Department of War|War Department]] from 1883 to 1885. In 1885, he engaged in newspaper work in Knoxville. He then returned to Decatur, Alabama, and continued the practice of law. He was the private secretary of Congressman [[Leonidas C. Houk]] from Tennessee in 1888, and was the city attorney of Decatur, Alabama.{{cite web|title=Richard W. Austin|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=A000341|publisher=Biographical Directory of the United States Congress|accessdate=1 May 2013}} Austin ran for Alabama's [[Alabama's 8th congressional district|8th district]] seat in the U.S. House of Representatives in 1890, but lost to the incumbent, former Confederate general [[Joseph Wheeler]], 16,821 votes to 12,076.[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=332308 Alabama District 8: 1890], Our Campaigns. Retrieved: 17 August 2013. He was a delegate to the [[1892 Republican National Convention]] at [[Minneapolis]]. He returned to Knoxville in 1893 to edit the ''Knoxville Republican''. Following the death of Leonidas Houk in 1891, the Tennessee Republican Party gradually split into two quarreling factions: one led by Brownlow, which Austin supported, and the other led by former congressman [[Henry Clay Evans]] of Chattanooga, which had the support of Chattanooga businessman [[Newell Sanders]]. At the [[1896 Republican National Convention]], Austin and Brownlow helped thwart Evans' bid for the vice presidential nomination. Brownlow was elected to Congress by the [[Tennessee's 1st congressional district|1st district]] later that year. The president considered Evans for the office of [[Postmaster General of the United States|Postmaster General]], but the appointment went to [[James A. Gary]] of [[Maryland]], due in part to the influence of Brownlow and Austin.Phillip Langsdon, ''Tennessee: A Political History'' (Franklin, Tenn.: Hillsboro Press, 2000), pp. 227-229. In 1897, President McKinley appointed Austin [[United States Marshals Service|United States Marshal]] for the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee|Eastern District of Tennessee]]. One of the more notable actions of Austin as marshal came in June 1903, when he organized an unsuccessful effort to recapture outlaw [[Kid Curry]], who had escaped from a Knoxville jail.Mark Smokov, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=5-kosT_32RcC&pg=PA268&dq=%22r.+w.+austin%22+tennessee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=LXAOUujiMa242QXI3IHgBA&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=%22r.%20w.%20austin%22%20tennessee&f=false He Rode with Butch and Sundance: The Story of Harvey (Kid Curry) Logan]'' (University of North Texas Press, 2012), pp. 268-270. Austin ran for Tennessee's [[Tennessee's 2nd congressional district|2nd district]] congressional seat in 1904, but was defeated in the primary by [[Nathan W. Hale]], who had the support of the Evans-Sanders block.Langsdon, ''Tennessee: A Political History'', p. 240. In 1906, Austin was appointed United States [[consul (representative)|consul]] at [[Glasgow, Scotland]]. He remained at this post until November 1907, when he resigned and returned to Tennessee to mount another congressional campaign. ==Congress== In 1908, the quarrel between the Evans-Sanders and Brownlow-Austin factions intensified when powerful Knoxville businessman [[William J. Oliver (industrialist)|William J. Oliver]], a friend of Brownlow and Austin, led a band of armed ruffians to the state party's convention in Nashville, where they beat up Sanders and chased away his supporters. Determined to defeat Hale, the Brownlow faction aligned itself with the [[Malcolm R. Patterson|Malcolm Patterson]] faction of the state's Democratic Party, which was facing a similar rift between supporters of Patterson and supporters of his gubernatorial opponent, [[Edward W. Carmack]]. The Brownlow Republicans offered to vote for Patterson for governor, and in return, Patterson Democrats would vote for Austin in the 2nd district congressional election. With this support, Austin edged Hale on election day, 15,337 votes to 14,528.Langsdon, ''Tennessee: A Political History'', pp. 251-253.[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=129406 Richard W. Austin], Our Campaigns. Retrieved: 17 August 2013. [[File:Richard-wilson-austin-2.jpg|left|180px|thumb|Congressman Austin, photographed by [[Harris & Ewing photo studio|Harris & Ewing]] in 1914]] Incensed, Hale and his supporters attempted unsuccessfully to prevent Austin from caucusing with House Republicans. [[John Chiles Houk]], who generally supported the Evans-Sanders faction, convinced Patterson to abandon his support for Austin and Brownlow. This move proved untimely, however, as Patterson's popularity plummeted due to his actions in the aftermath of the Cooper-Carmack shootout. Though Hale had the support of Houk and the influential ''Knoxville Journal'', Austin had the support of President [[William Howard Taft]].Langsdon, ''Tennessee: A Political History'', pp. 261-265. Following a savage campaign in 1910, Austin again defeated Hale, this time by a margin of 15,761 votes to 11,755. In 1912, Republicans were again divided, with some remaining loyal to Taft, and others throwing their support behind [[Theodore Roosevelt]] and the [[Progressive Party (United States, 1912)|Progressive Party]] ticket. In the 2nd district congressional election, Austin remained loyal to Taft and ran on the Republican ticket. W. H. Buttram, who had the support of John Chiles Houk and Knoxville attorney [[Hugh B. Lindsay]], ran on the Progressive ticket. J.C.J. Williams ran as a Democrat. Though Roosevelt outpolled Taft in the 2nd district, Austin was easily reelected, garnering 12,712 votes to 7,025 for Buttram, and 6,681 for Williams.Langsdon, ''Tennessee: A Political History'', pp. 278-280. Austin was easily reelected in 1914 and 1916. At the [[1916 Republican National Convention]], he openly squabbled with ex-Governor [[Ben W. Hooper]] (a Sanders ally) over the state's delegate to the national committee.''[https://books.google.com/books?id=74MMAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA104&dq=%22r.+w.+austin%22+tennessee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bnUOUu2lM7CQyQHPxoCgAQ&ved=0CCwQ6AEwADgo#v=onepage&q=%22r.%20w.%20austin%22%20tennessee&f=false Official Report of the Proceedings of the Sixteenth Republican National Convention]," (Tenny Press, 1916), p. 104. The persistent enmity of Houk, Sanders and Hooper finally took its toll in the March 1918 Republican primary, when Austin was defeated for the nomination by state party chairman [[J. Will Taylor]].Langsdon, ''Tennessee: A Political History'', pp. 288-296. During his five terms in Congress, Austin, a Taft ally, generally supported protectionist measures, such as tariffs on foreign imports.''[https://books.google.com/books?id=DrYmAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA155&dq=%22r.+w.+austin%22+tennessee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SXgOUt-4JoHXygGFlIGYAw&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAzgy#v=onepage&q=%22r.%20w.%20austin%22%20tennessee&f=false Credit & Financial Management]'', Volume 16 (1916), p. 155. In February 1911, Austin delivered a memorial address on the House floor for Brownlow, who had died the previous year."[https://books.google.com/books?id=W-Y3AQAAIAAJ&pg=RA4-PA40&dq=%22It+is+with+the+most+profound+feeling+of+sorrow+that+I+rise%22+brownlow&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1R0QUqm2NKLD2QXq8oHgCg&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22It%20is%20with%20the%20most%20profound%20feeling%20of%20sorrow%20that%20I%20rise%22%20brownlow&f=false Address of Mr. Austin, of Tennessee]," ''House Documents for the 61st Congress'', December 5, 1910 - March 4, 1911, p. 40. In 1915, he supported a national exchange system that would help match job seekers with employers looking for help.Udo Sautter, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2E0jZ5VlUkEC&pg=PA83&dq=%22richard+w.+austin%22+tennessee&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Pm4OUqiuLLOByQGoz4HQBw&ved=0CF0Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22richard%20w.%20austin%22%20tennessee&f=false Three Cheers for the Unemployed: Government and Unemployment Before the New Deal]'' (Cambridge University Press, 1991), p. 83. During the House debate on the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|19th Amendment]] in January 1918, Austin, referring to Congressman [[Jeannette Rankin]] of Montana, argued, "The highest, best, and strongest evidence that women's suffrage is a success has been established in this House by the enviable record made by our colleague from Montana, who has won the respect, confidence, and admiration of the members and officials of this House."Norma Smith, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Q85tHVOJR50C&pg=PA125&dq=%22richard+wilson+austin%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yGsOUu-7FaWqyQHb3YHQDQ&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22richard%20wilson%20austin%22&f=false Jeannette Rankin, America's Conscience]'' (Montana Historical Society, 2002), p. 125. ==Death== Austin died in [[Washington, D.C.]], on April 20, 1919, just over a month after the end of his final congressional term. He is [[burial|interred]] at [[Old Gray Cemetery]] in Knoxville, Tennessee.{{cite web|title=Richard W. Austin|url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/austin.html|publisher=The Political Graveyard|accessdate=1 May 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{CongBio|A000341}}
{{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox |state= Tennessee |district= 2 |before= [[Nathan W. Hale]] |after= [[J. Will Taylor]] |years=1909-1919}} {{s-end}} {{USCongRep-start|congresses= 61st–65th [[United States Congress]]es |state=[[Tennessee]]}} {{USCongRep/TN/61}} {{USCongRep/TN/61/2}} {{USCongRep/TN/62}} {{USCongRep/TN/62/2}} {{USCongRep/TN/62/3}} {{USCongRep/TN/62/4}} {{USCongRep/TN/63}} {{USCongRep/TN/64}} {{USCongRep/TN/65}} {{USCongRep-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Austin, Richard Wilson}} [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1919 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians from Decatur, Alabama]] [[Category:Politicians from Knoxville, Tennessee]] [[Category:University of Tennessee alumni]] [[Category:Tennessee lawyers]] [[Category:Tennessee Republicans]] [[Category:Clerks]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Tennessee]] [[Category:United States Marshals]] [[Category:American consuls]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Alabama Republicans]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]]

'''Robert Jeffrey Art''' is Christian A. Herter Professor of [[International Relations]] at [[Brandeis University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brandeis.edu/facguide/person.html?emplid=4d0a125256afd15e484fd8bf9819d86090d0a846|title=Robert Art|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnas.org/node/269 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=February 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100924053407/http://cnas.org/node/269 |archivedate=September 24, 2010 }}</ref> and Fellow at [[MIT Center for International Studies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/cis/dir_faculty.html|title=MIT CIS: About CIS: Directory|publisher=}}</ref> He subscribes to the theory of [[neorealism (international relations)|neorealism]], which argues that force still underlies the power structure in the modern world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/ssp/people/art/fellow_art.html|title=MIT Security Studies Program: Advisors - Bob Art|publisher=}}</ref> He is a member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/about/membership/roster.html?letter=A|title=Membership Roster|work=Council on Foreign Relations|accessdate=2016-03-28}}</ref>
== Life == Professor Art received his B.A. from [[Columbia College, Columbia University|Columbia College]] in 1964 and his Ph.D. from [[Harvard University]] in 1968.
Professor Art is a former member of the [[Secretary of Defense of the United States|Secretary of Defense's]] Long Range Planning Staff (1982) and a former Dean of the [[Brandeis University#Graduate School of Arts and Sciences (GSAS)|Graduate School of Arts and Sciences]] at Brandeis, and has consulted for the Central Intelligence Agency. He is a member of the editorial boards of the scholarly journals [[International Security]], [[Political Science Quarterly]], and [[Security Studies]]. Since 1982, he has also co-edited [[Cornell University|Cornell University's]] "Series in Security Studies."
He has lectured at numerous American universities and research institutes and at the following U.S. military and foreign institutions: the [[U.S. Army War College]], the U.S. National War College, [[U.S. Military Academy|West Point]], the [[U.S. Air Force Academy]], the [[Marine Corps University|U.S. Marine Command and Staff College]], the [[Air Command and Staff College|U.S. Air Force Command and Staff College]], the [[Air University (United States Air Force)|U.S. Air University]], the [[U.S. Naval Postgraduate School]], the [[Industrial College of the Armed Forces|U.S. Industrial College of the Armed Forces]], the National War College (Beijing), the [[Renmin University of China|People's University]] (Beijing), the Institute for War Studies ([[King's College London|King's College]], [[London]]), the [[Free University of Berlin]], the Konrad Adenauer Institute (Berlin), the [[NATO School]] ([[Oberammergau]]), and the [[Führungsakademie der Bundeswehr]] ([[Hamburg]]).
== Miscellaneous views == Art has been critical of NATO's expansion, writing presciently in 1998 that
{{Quote|The United States and its NATO allies have gotten themselves into a real pickle […] [w]ith their decision to enlarge NATO by taking in Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic […] How large can a NATO-without-Russia become before the West more or less permanently alienates Russia? […] Taking in Ukraine without also inducting Russia is the quickest way to alienate Russia […] and would justifiably give rise within Russia to fears of encirclement by, and exclusion from, the West.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Art | first = Robert J. | authorlink = Robert J. Art | year = 1998 | title = Creating a Disaster: NATO's Open Door Policy | journal = Political Science Quarterly | volume = 113 | number = 3 | pages = 383–403 | jstor = 2658073 }} Quotes on pp. 383–4.</ref> }}
== Awards == He has received grants from the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University, the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] (International Affairs Fellow), the [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]], the [[Ford Foundation]], the United States Institute of Peace, and the Century Foundation.
== Selected Works == * ''The TFX Decision: McNamara and the Military'' (1968) * ''A Grand Strategy for America'' (2003) – a finalist for the Arthur B. Ross Award of the Council on Foreign Relations * ''Reorganizing America's Defense'' (1985) -- contributor and co-editor, with Samuel P. Huntington and Vincent Davis) * ''U.S. Foreign Policy: the Search for a New Role'' (1993) -- contributor and co-editor with Seyom Brown * ''The United States and Coercive Diplomacy'' (2003) -- contributor and co-editor with Patrick Cronin * ''Democracy and Counterterrorism'' (2007) -- contributor and co-editor with Louise Richardson * ''America's Grand Strategy and World Politics'' (2009)
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.brandeis.edu/facguide/faculty?emplid=4d0a125256afd15e484fd8bf9819d86090d0a846 Brandeis Faculty Guide] *[http://web.mit.edu/SSP/people/art/fellow_art.html MIT Security Studies Program] *[http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/experts/397/robert_art.html Belfer Center at Harvard]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Art, Robert J.}} [[Category:Political realists]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Brandeis University faculty]] [[Category:International relations scholars]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]]
